9.8 }} '''3548 Eurybates''' ({{IPAc-en|j|uː|r|ɪ|ˈ|b|eɪ|t|iː|z}} {{Respell|yoo|ri|BAY|teez}}), provisional designation ''{{mp|1973 SO}}'', is a carbonaceous [[Jupiter trojan]] from the [[Greek camp]] and the parent body of the [[Eurybates family]], approximately {{convert|68|km|mi|abbr=off|sigfig=2|sp=us}} in diameter. It is a target to be visited by the [[Lucy (spacecraft)|''Lucy'' mission]] in August 2027. Discovered during the second [[Palomar–Leiden Trojan survey]] in 1973, it was later named after [[Eurybates]] from Greek mythology. The [[C-type asteroid|C]]/[[P-type asteroid]] belongs to the [[#Largest Jupiter trojans|60 largest Jupiter trojans]] and has a [[rotation period]] of 8.7 hours. == Discovery == ''Eurybates'' was discovered on 19 September 1973, by Dutch astronomers [[Ingrid van Houten-Groeneveld|Ingrid]] and [[Cornelis van Houten]] at [[Leiden Observatory|Leiden]], on photographic plates taken by [[Tom Gehrels]] at the [[Palomar Observatory]] in California, United States. In 1951, it was first observed as ''{{mp|1954 CB}}'' at the [[Goethe Link Observatory]], extending the asteroid's [[observation arc]] by 22 years prior to its official discovery observation at Palomar. Since the discovery of [[588 Achilles]] by [[Max Wolf]] in 1906, more than 7000 Jupiter trojans, with nearly 4600 bodies in the [[Greek camp]], have already been discovered. === Palomar–Leiden Trojan survey === While the discovery date aligns with the second [[Palomar–Leiden Trojan survey]], ''Eurybates'' has not received a {{nowrap|"T-2"}} prefixed [[survey designation]], which was assigned for the discoveries made by the fruitful collaboration between the Palomar and Leiden observatories in the 1960s and 1970s. Gehrels used Palomar's [[Samuel Oschin telescope]] (also known as the 48-inch Schmidt Telescope), and shipped the [[photographic plate]]s to Ingrid and Cornelis van Houten at Leiden Observatory where [[astrometry]] was carried out. The trio are credited with the discovery of [[:Category:Discoveries by the Palomar–Leiden survey|several thousand asteroids]]. == Orbit and classification == ''Eurybates'' is a dark Jovian [[asteroid]] orbiting in the leading Greek camp at Jupiter's {{L4}} [[Lagrangian point]], 60[[degree (angle)|°]] ahead of the Gas Giant's orbit in a [[Orbital resonance|1:1 resonance]] ''(see [[Trojans in astronomy]])''. It orbits the Sun at a distance of 4.7–5.7 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] once every 11 years and 10 months (4,321 days; [[semi-major axis]] of 5.19 AU). Its orbit has an [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] of 0.09 and an [[orbital inclination|inclination]] of 8[[Degree (angle)|°]] with respect to the [[ecliptic]]. === Eurybates family === ''Eurybates'' is the [[parent body]] of the small [[Eurybates family]] ({{small|[[FIN tbl#005|005]]}}), with 218 known members of carbonaceous and/or primitive composition.{{rp|23}} Only a few [[Asteroid family|families]] have been identified among the Jovian asteroids; four of them in the Greek camp. This potentially collisional family was first characterized by Jakub Rozehnal and Miroslav Brož in 2011, and further described in 2014. Members of this family include the Jupiter trojans {{mpl|(5258) 1989 AU|1}}, [[8060 Anius]], [[9818 Eurymachos]], {{mpl|(163189) 2002 EU|6}}, {{mpl|(287577) 2003 FE|42}} and [[360072 Alcimedon]]. == Physical characteristics == ''Eurybates'' has been characterized as a carbonaceous [[C-type asteroid]] by both the [[Lucy (spacecraft)|''Lucy'']] mission team and [[Brian D. Warner|Brian Warner]]'s ''Lightcurve Data Base''. The overall [[Asteroid spectral type|spectral type]] for members of the Eurybates family is that of a C- and [[P-type asteroid|P-type]].{{rp|23}} === Rotational lightcurves === In May 1992, a rotational [[lightcurve]] of ''Eurybates'' was obtained from [[Photometry (astronomy)|photometric]] observations by [[Stefano Mottola]] and Maria Gonano–Beurer using the now decommissioned [[ESO 1-metre telescope]] at [[La Silla Observatory]] in northern Chile. Lightcurve analysis gave a [[rotation period]] of 8.711 hours with a brightness variation of 0.20 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=3-]]}}). In October 2010, photometric observations by American astronomer [[Robert D. Stephens|Robert Stephens]] at the Goat Mountain Astronomical Research Station {{Obscode|G79}} in California gave a concurring period of 8.73 hours and an amplitude of 0.19 [[Magnitude (astronomy)|magnitude]] ({{small|[[LCDB quality code|U=2+]]}}). ''Eurybates'' has two determined [[Poles of astronomical bodies|spin axes]] at (143.0°, −45.0°) and/or (325.0°, –61.0°) in [[Ecliptic coordinate system|ecliptic coordinates]] (λ, β). === Diameter and albedo === According to the surveys carried out by the Infrared Astronomical Satellite [[IRAS]], the Japanese [[Akari (satellite)|Akari]] satellite, and NASA's [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]] with its subsequent [[NEOWISE]] mission, ''Eurybates'' measures between 63.89 and 72.14 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an [[astronomical albedo|albedo]] between 0.052 and 0.060. The ''Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link'' agrees with IRAS, and derives an albedo of 0.0491 and a diameter of 72.08 kilometers with an [[absolute magnitude]] of 9.6. {{Largest Jupiter trojans}} == Naming == This [[minor planet]] was named after [[Eurybates]], the Ancient hero from [[Greek mythology]], who was a [[herald]] for the Greek armies during the [[Trojan War]]. The official naming citation was published by the [[Minor Planet Center]] on 28 April 1991 ({{small|[[Minor Planet Circulars|M.P.C.]] 18138}}). == ''Lucy'' mission target == ''Eurybates'' is planned to be visited by the [[Lucy (spacecraft)|''Lucy'' spacecraft]] which will launch in 2021. The fly by is scheduled for 12 August 2027, and will approach the asteroid to a distance of 1000 kilometers at a velocity of 5.8 kilometers per second and a solar [[phase angle (astronomy)|phase angle]] of 81°. The mission's six targets in chronological order with their flyby dates are:https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2017/pdf/2025.pdf * [[52246 Donaldjohanson]] — 20 April 2025: 4 km diameter C-type asteroid in the inner main-belt, member of ~130Myr old Erigone family; * '''3548 Eurybates''' — 12 August 2027: 64 km diameter C-type Jupiter Trojan in the Greek camp at {{L4}}, largest member of the only confirmed disruptive collisional family in the Trojans; * [[15094 Polymele]] — 15 September 2027: 21 km diameter P-type Trojan at {{L4|nolink=yes}}, likely collisional fragment; * [[11351 Leucus]] — 18 April 2028: 34 km diameter D-type [[List of slow rotators (minor planets)|slow rotator]] Trojan at {{L4|nolink=yes}}; * [[21900 Orus]] — 11 November 2028: 51 km diameter D-type Trojan at {{L4|nolink=yes}}; * [[617 Patroclus]] — 2 March 2033: P-type [[binary asteroid|binary]] Trojan. The primary, Patroclus, has a mean diameter of 113 km and its companion, Menoetius, has a diameter of 104 km. The pair orbit at a separation of 680 km. [[World War II]] * [[Burma Campaign]] | mawards = [[File:Hilal-Jurat Ribbon.gif|20px]] [[Hilal-e-Jurat]] | military_blank1 = | military_data1 = | military_blank2 = | military_data2 = | military_blank3 = | military_data3 = | military_blank4 = | military_data4 = | military_blank5 = | military_data5 = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | footnotes = }} '''Mohammad Ayub Khan''' ({{lang-ur|{{Nastaliq|محمد ایوب خان}}}}; 14 May 1907 – 19 April 1974), {{small|[[Civil decorations of Pakistan|HPk]], [[Nishan-e-Pakistan|NPk]], [[Hilal-e-Jurat|HJ]], [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]]}}, was a Pakistani [[Dictator|military dictator]] and the [[List of Presidents of Pakistan|second]] [[President of Pakistan]] who [[Usurper|forcibly assumed]] the presidency from [[Iskander Mirza|first President]] through [[1958 Pakistani coup d'état|coup]] in 1958, the first successful coup d'état of the country. The popular demonstrations and labour strikes which were supported by the [[1969 uprising in East Pakistan|protests in East Pakistan]] ultimately led to his [[forced resignation]] in 1969.{{cite web |url=http://www.pakistanherald.com/newprofile.aspx?hofid=1180 |title=Muhammad Ayub Khan the Second President of Pakistan |publisher=Pakistan Herald.com |accessdate=16 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120317055424/http://www.pakistanherald.com/newprofile.aspx?hofid=1180 |archivedate=17 March 2012 }}, Retrieved 25 August 2015 Trained at the British [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst|Royal Military College]], Ayub Khan fought in the [[World War II]] as a [[Colonel (United Kingdom)|Colonel]] in the [[British Indian Army]] before [[Pakistani citizenship|deciding to transfer]] to join the [[Pakistan Army]] as an aftermath of [[Partition of India|partition]] of [[British India]] in 1947. His command assignment included his role as [[Chief of Army Staff of the Bangladesh Army|chief of staff]] of [[Pakistan Eastern Command|Eastern Command]] in [[East Bengal|East-Bengal]] and elevated as the first native [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|commander-in-chief]] of [[Pakistan Army]] in 1951 by then-[[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] [[Liaquat Ali Khan]] in a controversial promotion over several senior officers.{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystudies.us/pakistan/18.htm|title= Ayub Khan in US Country Studies |publisher=US State Department|accessdate=16 November 2011}}, Retrieved 25 August 2015 From 1953–58, he served in the [[Ministry of Talents|civilian government]] as [[Defence Minister of Pakistan|Defence]] and [[Interior Minister of Pakistan|Home Minister]] and supported Iskander Mirza's decision to impose martial law against Prime Minister Feroze Khan's [[Feroze Khan administration|administration]] in 1958.{{cite web|title=Ouster of President Iskander Mirza|url=http://www.storyofpakistan.com/articletext.asp?artid=A117|publisher=Story of Pakistan, part-II}}, Retrieved 27 August 2015 Two weeks later, he took over the presidency from Mirza after the meltdown of [[Civil military relations|civil-military relations]] between the military and the civilian President.{{cite web|title=Field Marshal Ayub Khan Becomes President [1962–1969]|url=http://www.storyofpakistan.com/articletext.asp?artid=A067|publisher=Story of Pakistan, Part-1}}, Retrieved 25 August 2015{{cite web |url=http://pkpolitics.com/2011/05/25/kal-tak-25-may-2011/ |title=Kal Tak – 25 May 2011 | Pakistan Politics |publisher=Pkpolitics.com |date= |accessdate=9 December 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130509011515/http://pkpolitics.com/2011/05/25/kal-tak-25-may-2011/ |archive-date=9 May 2013 |dead-url=yes }} After appointing General [[Musa Khan]] as an [[Army Chief of Staff (Pakistan)|army chief]] in 1958, the policy inclination towards the [[CENTO|alliance]] with the United States was pursued that saw the allowance of American access to [[List of Pakistan Air Force Bases|facilities]] inside Pakistan, most notably the [[Peshawar Air Station|airbase]] outside of [[Peshawar]], from which [[U-2 incident|spy missions]] over the [[Soviet Union]] were launched."Story of Pakistan, Part-1"/, Retrieved 25 August 2015 [[China–Pakistan relations#Military relations|Relations with]] neighboring China were strengthened but deteriorated with [[Pakistan-Soviet Union relations|Soviet Union]] in 1962, and with [[India]] in 1965. His presidency saw the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|war with India]] in 1965 which ended with Soviet Union facilitating the [[Tashkent Declaration]] between [[India and Pakistan|two nations]]. At home front, the [[Privatisation in Pakistan|policy of privatisation]] and [[Industry of Pakistan|industrialization]] was introduced that made the [[Economy of Pakistan|country's economy]] as [[Four Asian Tigers|Asia's fastest-growing]] economies. During his tenure, several infrastructure programs were built that consisted the completion of [[List of power stations in Pakistan|hydroelectric stations]], [[List of dams and reservoirs in Pakistan|dams and reservoirs]], as well as prioritizing the [[Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission|space program]] but reducing the [[Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program|nuclear deterrence]]. In 1965, Ayub Khan entered in a [[Pakistani presidential election, 1965|presidential race]] as [[Pakistan Muslim League|PML candidate]] to counter the popular and famed [[Nonpartisan|non-partisan]] [[Fatima Jinnah]] and controversially reelected for the second term. He was faced with allegations of widespread intentional [[vote rigging]]s, authorized political murders in [[Karachi]], and the politics over the unpopular peace treaty with India which many Pakistanis considered an embarrassing compromise. In 1967, he was widely disapproved when the demonstrations across the country were led by [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] over the [[Price/wage spiral|price hikes]] of [[Food consumption|food consumer]] products and, dramatically fell amid the [[1969 uprising in East Pakistan|popular uprising]] in East led by [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman|Mujibur Rahman]] in 1969. Forced to resign to avoid further protests while inviting army chief [[Yahya Khan]] to impose martial law for the second time, he fought a brief [[Paralysis|illness]] and died in 1974. His legacy remains mixed; he is credited with an ostensible [[Economic boom|economic prosperity]] and what [[PML(Q)|supporters]] dub the "decade of development", but is criticized for beginning the first of the [[Pakistani Intelligence Community|intelligence agencies' incursions]] into the [[Politics in Pakistan|national politics]], for concentrating corrupt wealth in a [[Oligarchy|few hands]], and [[Geographical segregation|segregated policies]] that later led to the [[Breakup of East and West Pakistan|breaking-up of nation's unity]] that resulted in the [[Bangladesh Liberation War|creation of Bangladesh]].{{cite web|title=Martial Law Under Field Marshal Ayub Khan [1958–62]|url=http://www.storyofpakistan.com/articletext.asp?artid=A065|publisher=Story of Pakistan, Part-3}}, Retrieved 25 August 2015[http://www.dawn.com/news/1293604/what-they-never-tell-us-about-ayub-khans-regime Dawn daily, Aug 2015 article and review] == Early years and personal life == Ayub Khan was born on 14 May 1907 in Rehana, a village in [[Haripur District]] in [[Hazara region]]{{cite web |url=http://www.storyofpakistan.com/person.asp?perid=P017 |title=Muhammad Ayub Khan |website=Story of Pakistan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317091119/http://www.storyofpakistan.com/person.asp?perid=P017 |archivedate=17 March 2010 |access-date=29 April 2010}}{{cite book |last1=Lyon |first1=Peter |date=2008 |title=Conflict between India and Pakistan: An Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vLwOck15eboC&pg=PA23 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |location= |page=23 |isbn=978-1-57607-712-2 |access-date=22 August 2010}} of then [[North-West Frontier Province (1901–1955)|North-West Frontier Province]] (now [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa]], Pakistan). He hailed from the [[Tareen]]{{Cite book|title=Pakistan and the emergence of Islamic militancy in Afghanistan|last1=Hussain|first1=Rizwan|authorlink=|volume=|year=2005|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd|location=|isbn=978-0-7546-4434-7|page=74|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TRW_M_xybyYC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA74#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=22 August 2010}}http://www.dawn.com/news/1025073/where-pragmatism-holds-sway. Retrieved 10 April 2018.http://tribune.com.pk/story/897889/forming-the-govt-pml-n-seeks-haripur-tehsil-triumph-through-bloodlines/. Retrieved 11 April 2018.Sir Olaf Caroe, "The Pathans 550 B.C.-A.D. 1957". Oxford University Press {{ISBN|978-0-19-577221-0}}. Page 453. tribe of ethnic [[Pashtun people|Pashtuns]] settled in Hazara region.{{Cite book|title=A history of Pakistan and its origins|last1=Jaffrelot|first1=Christophe |authorlink=|volume=|year=2004|publisher=Anthem Press|location=|isbn=978-1-84331-149-2|page=69|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q9sI_Y2CKAcC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA69#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=22 August 2010}} He was the first child of the second wife of [[Mir Dad Khan|Mir Dad]], a [[Risaldar-Major]] (a regimental [[junior commissioned officer|JCO]] which was then known as [[viceroy's commissioned officer|VCO]]) in the [[9th Hodson's Horse]] which was a cavalry regiment of the [[British Indian Army]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} For his basic education, he was enrolled in a school in Sarai Saleh, which was about 4 miles from his village.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} He used to go to school on a [[mule]]'s back and was shifted to a school in Haripur, where he started living with his grandmother.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} He went on to study at [[Aligarh Muslim University]] (AMU) and {{cite book|last1=Malik|first1=Iftikhar Haider|title=The History of Pakistan|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780313341373|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Z6NfsuDACQwC&pg=PA146&dq=ayub+khan+aligarh#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20aligarh&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|year=2008}}{{rp|146}} while pursuing his college education, he was accepted into the [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst|Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst]] by the recommendation of General [[Andrew Skeen]]; he did not complete his degree and departed for Great Britain.{{rp|147}}Karl J. Newman: Pakistan under Ayub Khan, Bhutto und Zia-ul-Haq. S. 31, {{ISBN|3-8039-0327-0}}. Ayub Khan was fluent in Urdu, English and his regional [[Hindko dialect]] as well as [[Pashto]].''The Political Dilemmas of Military Regimes'' (1985), by Christopher S. Clapham, George D. E. Philip, p. 203.{{Cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=keEl6QKnuoYC&pg=PA130&lpg=PA130&dq=ayub+khan+was+pashtun#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20was%20pashtun&f=false | title=Martial races of undivided India| isbn=9788178357751| last1=Tyagi| first1=Vidya Prakash| year=2009}} == Military career == [[File:Ayub khan wih quaid.PNG|thumb|upright|left|[[Brigadier|Brig.]] Ayub Khan meeting with [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah|Jinnah]], [[circa|ca.]] 1947.]] According to some accounts, Ayub Khan's performance at the Sandhurst Military Academy in the United Kingdom was good, earning him awards and scholarships.{{cite book|last1=Leonard|first1=Thomas M.|title=Encyclopedia of the Developing World|publisher=Psychology Press, Leonard|isbn=9781579583880|url=https://books.google.com/?id=3mE04D9PMpAC&pg=PA125&dq=ayub+khan+commander#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=27 October 2005}}{{rp|124–125}} He was [[commissioned officer|commissioned]] as a [[Second Lieutenant|2nd Lt.]] on 2 February 1928 in the 1/14th Punjab Regiment (1st Battalion of the 14th Punjab Regiment) of the British Indian Army — it is now known as the 5th battalion of the [[Punjab Regiment (Pakistan)|Punjab Regiment]] of [[Pakistan Army]].{{rp|125}}Indian Army List, 1928 Dec Amongst those who passed out with him was the future [[Chief of the Army Staff (India)|chief of army staff]] of the [[Indian Army]], General [[Joyanto Nath Chaudhuri|J. N. Chaudhri]] who served as chief when Ayub was the President of Pakistan.{{London Gazette|issue=33353|page=766|date=3 February 1928}} After the standard probationary period of service in the [[British Army]], he was appointed to the British Indian Army on 10 April 1929, joining the [[19th Punjabis|1/14th Punjab Regiment ''Sherdils'']], now known as 5th Punjab Regiment.{{London Gazette|issue=33510|page=4274|date=28 June 1929}} He was promoted to Lieutenant on 2 May 1930 and to [[Captain (army)|Captain]] on 2 February 1937.{{London Gazette|issue=33613|page=3572|date=6 June 1930}}{{London Gazette|issue=34381|page=1827|date=19 March 1937}} During [[World War II]], he was promoted to the temporary rank of [[Lieutenant-Colonel]] in 1942 and was posted in Burma to participate in [[Burma Campaign 1942–1943|first phase]] of [[Burma Campaign|Burma Front]] in 1942–43.{{cite book|last1=Burki|first1=Shahid Javed|title=Historical Dictionary of Pakistan|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield, Burki|isbn=9781442241480|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rk-sBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA87&dq=ayub+khan+world+war+II#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20world%20war%20II&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=19 March 2015}}{{rp|87–88}} He was promoted to the permanent rank of [[Major]] on 2 February 1945.{{London Gazette|issue=37085|page=2577|date=18 May 1945}} Later that year, he was promoted to temporary [[Colonel]] and assumed the command of his own regiment in which he was commissioned to direct operations on [[Burma Campaign 1944–1945|second phase]] of Burma Front; however he was soon [[Leave of absence|suspended without pay]] from that command temporarily for visible cowardice under fire.See accounts of Sardar [[Shaukat Hayat Khan]] ''The Nation that Lost its Soul: Memoirs'', Lahore: Jang Publications, 1992, p 187; and Lt Col (r) HE Empson 'Hard Times- The Burmese Campaign 1942–1945' Aldershot: Gale and Polden, 1952 In 1946, he was posted back to [[British Raj|British India]] and was stationed in the [[North-West Frontier Province (1901–1955)|North-West Frontier Province]]. In 1947, he was promoted to a [[One-star rank|one-star]] rank, [[Brigadier]], and commanded a [[Brigade combat team|Brigade]] in mountainous [[South Waziristan]].{{rp|87}} When the United Kingdom [[Indian Independence Act 1947|announced]] the [[Partition of India|partition British India]] into [[India]] and [[Pakistan]], he was one of the most senior serving officers in the British Indian Army who [[Pakistani citizenship|decided to opt]] for Pakistan in 1947.{{rp|125}}{{rp|87}} At the time of his joining, the [[Indian Army]] sent the military seniority list to Pakistan's [[Ministry of Defence (Pakistan)|Ministry of Defence]] (MoD) where he was the 10th ranking officer in terms of seniority with [[Service number|Service No.]] PA-010.{{cite book|last1=Nawaz|first1=Shuja|title=Crossed swords : Pakistan, its army, and the wars within|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press, Nawaz|location=Karachi|isbn=9780195476606}}{{rp|94}} In the early part of 1948, he was given the command of the [[Structure of the Pakistan Army|14th Infantry Division]] as its [[General Officer Commanding|GOC]], (still ranked Brigadier) stationed in [[Dacca]], [[East Pakistan|East-Pakistan]].{{rp|94}} In 1949, he was appointed as army commander of [[Pakistan Eastern Command|Eastern Command]]{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} and decorated with the [[Hilal-i-Jurat]] (HJ) by Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan]] for non-combatant service and called back to [[General Headquarters (Pakistan Army)|Army GHQ]] as an [[Adjutant General|adjutant-general]] on November of same year.{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} === Commander-in-chief === {{further|Commander-in-Chief (Pakistan Army)}} [[File:Ayubnewarmychief.jpg|thumb|left|upright|left|General Ayub Khan arriving to take command of the [[Pakistan Army]] in 17 January 1951.]] [[Lieutenant-General (United Kingdom)|Lieutenant General]] [[Douglas Gracey|Sir Douglas Gracey]] relinquished the command of the Pakistan Army on 23 January 1951, under pressure of calls for "nationalisation" of the army.{{citation |last=Ankit |first=Rakesh |title=The Defiant Douglas |newspaper=Epilogue |volume=4 |number=1 |pp=46–47 |date=January 2010 |url=https://issuu.com/epilogue/docs/january_10}} The [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistan government]] already called for appointing native commanders-in-chief of army, [[Pakistan Air Force|air force]], [[Pakistan Navy|navy]] and dismissed deputation appointments from the [[British military]].{{cite book|last1=Cheema|first1=Pervaiz I.|last2=Riemer|first2=Manuel|title=Pakistan's Defence Policy 1947–58|publisher=Springer, Reimer|isbn=9781349209422|url=https://books.google.com/?id=CX6xCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA82&dq=Admiral+Choudhri#v=onepage&q=Admiral%20Choudhri&f=false |page=82 |accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=22 August 1990}}{{cite book|last1=Tudor|first1=Maya|title=The Promise of Power: The Origins of Democracy in India and Autocracy in Pakistan|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107032965|url=https://books.google.com/?id=N2-9ahosP94C&pg=PA30&dq=commander+in+chief+pakistan+ayub+1953#v=onepage&q=commander%20in%20chief%20pakistan%20ayub%201953&f=false |page=30 |accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=14 March 2013}} The [[GHQ (Pakistan Army)|Army GHQ]] sent the nomination papers to [[Prime Minister's Secretariat (Pakistan)|Prime Minister's Secretariat]] for the appointment of [[commander-in-chief]]. There were four-senior officers in the race: [[Major General|Major-General]] [[Muhammed Akbar Khan|Akbar Khan]], Major-General [[Iftikhar Khan]], Major-General [[Ishfakul Majid]], and Major-General N.A.M. Raza, among these officers Akbar was the senior-most as he was commissioned in 1920.{{cite news |last=Siddiqui |first=A. R. |date=25 April 2004 |title=Army's top slot: the seniority factor |url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1065891 |newspaper=Dawn}} Initially, it was Gen. [[Iftikhar Khan]] (commissioned in 1929) who was selected to be appointed as first native commander-in-chief of the army, but he died in an airplane crash en route to take command after finishing the senior [[staff officer|staff officers']] course in the United Kingdom.{{cite news|last1=paksoldiers.com|title=Appointments of Pakistan Army Commanders and Historic Facts – Pakistan Military & Defence News|url=http://paksoldiers.com/2013/12/04/appointments-pakistan-army-commanders-historic-facts/|accessdate=3 November 2016|work=Original work published by the News International|agency=paksoldiers.com|publisher=paksoldiers.com|date=4 December 2013}} All three remaining generals were bypassed including the recommended senior-most Major-General [[Muhammed Akbar Khan|Akbar Khan]] and Major-General [[Ishfakul Majid]] (commissioned in 1924). The [[Defence Secretary of Pakistan|Defence Secretary]] [[Iskandar Mirza]], at that time, played a crucial role in lobbying for the army post selection as presenting with convincing arguments to Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]] to promote the junior-most Major-General Ayub Khan (commissioned in 1928, [[service number]]: PA-010) to the post despite the fact that his name was not included in the nomination list. Ayub's papers of promotion were controversially approved and he was appointed as the first native [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan)|Commander in Chief]] of Pakistan Army with a promotion to four-star rank, a full general, on 17 January 1951 by Prime Minister Ali Khan.{{rp|34}} Ayub's becoming the [[Army Chief of Staff (Pakistan)|army chief]] marked a change in the military tradition of preferring native Pakistanis; it ended the transitional role of [[British Armed Forces|British military]] officers.{{cite book|last=Haqqani|first=Hussain|title=Pakistan Between Mosque and Military|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC&pg=PA33&dq=liaquat+ali+khan+and+Ayub+Khan#v=onepage&q=liaquat%20ali%20khan%20and%20Ayub%20Khan&f=true|isbn=9780870032851|date=10 March 2010}} Although the [[Pakistani government]] announced the appointment of navy's native [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan)|commander in chief]] in 1951, it was Ayub Khan who helped [[Vice-Admiral]] [[Haji Mohammad Siddiq Choudri|M.S. Choudhri]] to be appointed as first native navy's commander in chief, also in 1953.{{cite book|last1=Cheema|first1=Pervaiz Iqbal|title=The Armed Forces of Pakistan|publisher=NYU Press, Cheema|isbn=9780814716335|url=https://books.google.com/?id=cw_gduyRv5oC&pg=PA93&dq=Vice+Admiral+choudri+1953#v=onepage&q=Vice%20Admiral%20choudri%201953&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|year=2002}}{{rp|93–94}} The events surrounding Ayub's appointment set the precedent for a native general being promoted out of turn, ostensibly because he was the least ambitious of the generals in the line of promotion and the most loyal to civil government at that time.The rule of seniority by Kamal Zafar Sunday 5 March 2006 [http://www.nation.com.pk/daily/mar-2006/5/columns5.php The Nation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311040129/http://www.nation.com.pk/daily/mar-2006/5/columns5.php |date=11 March 2007 }} Ayub, alongside [[HMS Choudri|Admiral Choudhri]], cancelled and disbanded the [[United Kingdom Armed Forces|British military]] tradition in the navy and the army when the U.S. military's [[Military Assistance Advisory Group|advisers]] were dispatched to the [[Pakistan Armed Forces|Pakistani military]] in 1955–57.{{cite web|last=Hamid Hussain |title=Tale of a love affair that never was: United States-Pakistan Defence Relations |url=http://www.defencejournal.com/2002/june/loveaffair.htm |website=Hamid Hussain, Defence Journal of Pakistan |publisher=Hamid Hussain, Defence Journal of Pakistan |accessdate=12 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304115412/http://www.defencejournal.com/2002/june/loveaffair.htm |archivedate=4 March 2012 }} British military traditions were only kept in the [[Pakistan Air Force|air force]] due to a [[Arthur McDonald|British commander]] and major staff consisting of [[Royal Air Force]] officers. In 1953, Ayub went on his first foreign visit [[Turkey]] as an [[Commander in Chief of the Pakistan Army|army c-in-c]], and was said to be impressed with [[Turkish Armed Forces|Turkish military]] tradition; he met only with the [[List of Ministers of National Defence of Turkey|Turkish Defence minister]] during his visit.{{cite book|last1=Yesilbursa|first1=Behcet Kemal|title=The Baghdad Pact: Anglo-American Defence Policies in the Middle East, 1950–59|publisher=Routledge, Yesilbursa|isbn=978-1135766863|url=https://books.google.com/?id=cZKRAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA26&dq=Ayub+Khan+medical+visit#v=onepage&q=Ayub%20Khan%20medical%20visit&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=8 July 2005}}{{rp|26}} Thereafter, he went to the United States and visited the [[United States Department of State|US State Department]] and [[The Pentagon|Pentagon]] to lobby for forging [[Pakistan-United States military relations|military relations]].{{rp|26}} He termed this visit as "medical visit" but made a strong plea for military aid which was not considered due to India's opposition.{{rp|27}} Three months before the end of his tenure as commander-in-chief of the army, Ayub Khan deposed his mentor, Iskandar Mirza, Pakistan's president, in a military coup – after Mirza had declared martial law and made Ayub Khan the chief martial law administrator.{{cite journal |last1=Wilcox |first1=Waynes Ayres |date=Summer 1965 |title=The Pakistan Coup d'Etat of 1958 |url= |journal=Pacific Affairs |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=142–163 |doi= |jstor=2753785}} === Cabinet and Defence Minister === {{further|Ministry of Talents|One Unit|Interservice rivalry}} In 1954, Prime Minister [[Muhammad Ali Bogra]]'s relations with the [[Military of Pakistan|military]] and [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|Ghulam Muhammad]] deteriorated on issues of the economy.{{cite book|last1=Bahadur|first1=Kalim|title=Democracy in Pakistan: Crises and Conflicts|publisher=Har-Anand Publications, Bahadur|isbn=9788124100837|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ND9yNyTpntYC&pg=PA191&dq=Ayub+Khan+Defence#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|year=1998}}{{rp|191}} Pressure had been built up to reconstruct the [[Cabinet of Pakistan|Cabinet]] which eventually witnessed with Lieutenant-General Ayub Khan becoming the [[Defence Minister of Pakistan|Defence Minister]] and [[Iskander Mirza]] as [[Interior Minister of Pakistan|Home Minister]] in 1954.{{rp|192}}{{cite book|last1=Dixit|first1=J. N.|title=India-Pakistan in War and Peace|publisher=Routledge, Dixit|isbn=9781134407583|url=https://books.google.com/?id=mdWCAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA124&dq=Ayub+Khan+interior+minister#v=onepage&q=Ayub%20Khan%20interior%20minister&f=false |page=124 |accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=2 September 2003}} On 24 February 1954, he signed the [[Central Treaty Organization]] (CENTO) and, together with Mirza, their role in the [[Politics of Pakistan|national politics]] began to grow.{{rp|192–193}} In 1954, the work on controversial program, the [[One Unit]], began which would integrate the [[Four Provinces (Pakistan)|four provinces]] into one united political entity, known as [[West Pakistan|West-Pakistan]], as a counterbalance to [[East Pakistan|East-Pakistan]].{{cite book|last1=Jaffrelot|first1=Christophe|title=The Pakistan Paradox: Instability and Resilience|publisher=Oxford University Press, Jeffrelot|isbn=9780190613303|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_XdeCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT181&dq=Ayub+Khan+interior+minister#v=onepage&q=Ayub%20Khan%20interior%20minister&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=15 July 2015}} Despite opposition from the ethnic parties and public in general, the program was launched by Prime Minister Bogra. In 1955, Prime Minister [[Muhammad Ali Bogra|Bogra]] was dismissed by [[Governor-General of Pakistan|Governor-General]] [[Malik Ghulam Muhammad|Muhammad]] and he was succeeded by the new Prime Minister [[Chaudhry Muhammad Ali|Muhammad Ali]] as the Defence Minister. As an after of [[East Pakistani legislative election, 1954|general elections]] in 1954 in [[East Pakistan|East]], the [[Awami League]] formed the government in East while the [[West Pakistan|West]] was governed by the [[Pakistan Muslim League|PML]], but the PML government collapse soon after in West in 1956. He was called on to join the Cabinet as Defence Minister by Prime Minister [[H. S. Suhrawardy|H.S. Suhrawardy]] and maintained closer relations with Iskander Mirza who now had become the [[List of Presidents of Pakistan|first]] [[President of Pakistan|President]] of the country after the successful promulgation of [[Constitution of Pakistan of 1956|Constitution]] in 1956. In 1957, President Mirza renewed his extension to serve as an [[Army Chief of Staff (Pakistan)|army chief of staff]].{{failed verification|date=October 2017}} Around this time, the [[Ministry of Defence (Pakistan)|MoD]] led by General Ayub Khan began to see the serious [[interservice rivalry]] between the [[GHQ (Pakistan Army)|Army GHQ]] staff and the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] staff.{{cite book|last1=Singh|first1=Ravi Shekhar Narain Singh|title=The Military Factor in Pakistan|publisher=Lancer Publishers, Singh|isbn=9780981537894|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wCm2DFZblOYC&pg=PA382&dq=Admiral+Choudhri#v=onepage&q=Admiral%20Choudhri&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|year=2008}}{{rp|381–382}} [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan Navy)|Commander in Chief]] of Navy Vice-Admiral [[Haji Mohammad Siddiq Choudri|M. S. Choudri]] and his NHQ staff had been fighting with the [[Ministry of Finance (Pakistan)|Finance ministry]] and the [[Ministry of Defense (Pakistan)|MoD]] over the issues of rearmament and contingency plans.{{rp|381–382}} Meanwhile, he continued to serve with Prime Minister [[I. I. Chundrigar|Chundrigar]] and [[Feroz Khan Noon|Feroz Noon]]'s government as Defence Minister, and his resentment towards civilian politicians grew. In 1958, he chaired the [[Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee|Joint Chiefs of Staff]] meeting where he became involved with heated discussion with Admiral [[Haji Mohammad Siddiq Choudri|M. S. Choudri]].{{cite web|last1=Hussain|first1=Hamid|title=National Security Decision Making Process|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/2002/march/process.htm|website=www.defencejournal.com|publisher=defencejournal.com|accessdate=3 November 2016}} He reportedly complained against [[Haji Mohammad Siddiq Choudri|Admiral Choudri]] to President Mirza and criticized Admiral Choudri for "neither having the brain, imagination or depth of thought to understand such (defence) problems nor the vision or the ability to make any contribution".{{cite news|last1=Ghani|first1=Nadia|title=NON-FICTION: The narcissist|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/826646|accessdate=3 November 2016|work=DAWN.COM|agency=Dawn newspapers|publisher=Dawn newspapers, Ghani|date=11 July 2010}} The impasse was broken with Admiral Choudhri resigning from the Navy in protest as result of having differences with [[Pakistan Navy|Navy]]'s plans of expansion and modernization.{{rp|381}}{{rp|94}} In 1958, Vice-Admiral [[Afzal Rahman Khan]], who was known to be confident of General Ayub Khan, was appointed as [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|naval chief]] by President Mirza.{{cite book|last1=Rizvi|first1=H.|title=Military, State and Society in Pakistan|publisher=Springer, Rizvi|isbn=9780230599048|url=https://books.google.com/?id=ZwGIDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA104&lpg=PA104&dq=Afzal+Rahman+Khan+admiral#v=onepage&q=Afzal%20Rahman%20Khan%20admiral&f=false|accessdate=1 November 2016|language=en|date=15 May 2000}}{{rp|104}} == President of Pakistan (1960–1969) == [[File:Mr. and Mrs. S.N. Bakar with General Ayub Khan and Mr. H.S. Suhrawardy (1958)..jpg|thumb|Ayub Khan in 1958 with [[Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy|H. S. Suhrawardy]] and Mr. and Mrs. [[Shaikh Nazrul Bakar|S. N. Bakar]].]] [[File:Queen Elizabeth II and the Prime Ministers of the Commonwealth Nations, at Windsor Castle (1960 Commonwealth Prime Minister's Conference).jpg|thumb|alt=A formal group of Elizabeth in tiara and evening dress with eleven prime ministers in evening dress or national costume.|Ayub Khan (back row, second from the right) with [[Elizabeth II]], former [[Queen of Pakistan]] at the 1960 [[Commonwealth Prime Minister's Conference]], [[Windsor Castle]]]] In a threat of being dismissed, Prime Minister [[H. S. Suhrawardy|H.S. Suhrawardy]] resigned and Prime Minister [[Ibrahim Ismail Chundrigar|I.I. Chundiragar]] took over the post but in mere two months he too tendered resignation after losing confidence in running the government.{{cite book|last1=Din|first1=Waheed Ud|title=The Marching Bells: A Journey of a Life Time|publisher=Author House, Din|isbn=9781456744144|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0JlCSH3Qnw0C&pg=PA49&dq=I+I+Chundrigar+Ayub#v=onepage&q=I%20I%20Chundrigar%20Ayub&f=false |page=49 |accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=16 May 2011}} The [[Constituent Assembly of Pakistan|Constituent Assembly]] elected [[Feroz Khan Noon|Sir Feroz Noon]] for the post of the Prime Minister who had much larger support from the Western [[Republican Party (Pakistan)|Republican Party]] and Eastern [[Awami League]], and [[Krishak Sramik Janata League|Krishak Sramik]]. This new alliance nearly threatened President [[Iskander Mirza]] because [[Huseyn Shaheed Suhrawardy|Suhrawardy]] and [[Feroz Khan Noon|Feroz]] were now initially campaigning to become Prime Minister and President in the next [[Elections in Pakistan|general elections]] to be held. The conservative [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)|Pakistan Muslim League]], led under its President [[Abdul Qayyum Khan|A.Q. Khan]], was also gaining momentum in West Pakistan and threatened for the ''[[Dharna]]'' movement.{{rp|83}} These events were against [[President of Pakistan|President]] Mirza hence he was willing to dissolve even Pakistan's [[One Unit]] for his advantage. On the midnight of 7 and 8 October 1958, [[President of Pakistan|President]] Mirza ordered a mass mobilization of [[Pakistan Armed Forces]] and abrogated the [[Constitution of Pakistan of 1956|Constitution]] after sending a letter to Prime Minister [[Feroz Khan Noon|Feroze]] and the [[Constituent Assembly of Pakistan|Constituent Assembly]] about the [[1958 Pakistani coup d'état|coup d'état]].{{rp|83}} Most of the politicians became only aware of coup the next morning; only the [[United States Ambassador to Pakistan|U.S. Ambassador]] [[James M. Langley|James Langley]] was kept aware of the political development in the country.{{rp|83}} President Mirza appointed General Ayub as its [[chief martial law administrator]] (CMLA) to enforce the [[1958 Pakistani coup d'état|martial law]] in both [[Enclave and exclave|exclave]]–West and East Pakistan.{{cite book|last1=Oborne|first1=Peter| authorlink =Peter Oborne|title=Wounded Tiger: A History of Cricket in Pakistan|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9781849832489|url=https://books.google.com/?id=EXXGBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA157&dq=iskander+mirza+martial+law#v=onepage&q=iskander%20mirza%20martial%20law&f=false |pages=157–158 |accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=9 April 2015}} However, President Mirza soon realized his mistake by making Ayub as the [[Chief martial law administrator|CMLA]] and [[repent]]ed his actions in [[News channels in Pakistan|news media]] about the delicate position he had gotten himself into.{{cite web|last1=SoP|title=Ouster of President Iskander Mirza|url=http://storyofpakistan.com/ouster-of-president-iskander-mirza|website=Story Of Pakistan, Mirza's ouster section|accessdate=3 November 2016|date=1 June 2003}} He regretted his decision and said: "I did not mean to do it," while offering assurances that the martial law would be for the shortest possible duration. In an attempt to consolidate the powers in his own control, Mirza unsuccessfully tried to appoint Ayub as [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime Minister]] the following and asked him to appoint the technocratic Cabinet. Such actions were not implemented due to Ayub Khan's protest against this attempt and briefly complained about Mirza's "[[high hand]]" methods.{{cite book|last1=Hiro|first1=Dilip|title=The Longest August: The Unflinching Rivalry Between India and Pakistan|publisher=Nation Books|isbn=9781568585031|url=https://books.google.com/?id=PpPCBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA149&dq=Mirza++Ayub+Khan%E2%80%99s+rivals#v=onepage&q=Mirza%20%20Ayub%20Khan%E2%80%99s%20rivals&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=24 February 2015}}{{rp|149–150}} President Mirza made a bold move by undercutting Ayub's rival in the army, navy, marines, and air force by co-opting military officers in his favors.{{rp|149–150}} Informed of President Mirza's chicanery, Ayub dispatched the military unit to enter in [[Aiwan-e-Sadr|presidential palace]] on the midnight of 26–27 October 1958 and placed him in a place to exile in to England.{{cite book|title=Army and Democracy: Military Politics in Pakistan|author=Aqil Shah|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=2014|isbn= 978-0-674-72893-6}} Subsequently, Admiral [[Afzal Rahman Khan|A. R. Khan]] and [[Gang of Four (Pakistan)|four army and air force generals]]: [[Azam Khan (general)|Azam]], [[Amir Mohammad Khan|Amir]], [[Wajid Ali Khan Burki|Wajid]], and [[Asghar Khan]] were instrumental in Ayub Khan's rise to power.{{rp|104}} Ouster of President Mirza was welcomed at public circles, [[Air Marshal]] [[Asghar Khan]], the [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan Air Force)|air force chief]] backed the actions for the martial law enforcement.{{rp|104}} He relieved the [[Pakistan Army|army command]] and appointed General [[Muhammad Musa]] as the new [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan Army)|army chief]] while he [[Self-coup|promoted himself]] to the [[Five-star rank|five-star]] rank, [[Field Marshal]]– a rank that many of his critics said that he never deserved.{{cite book|last1=Baig|first1=Muhammad Anwar; Ebad|title=Pakistan: Time for Change|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=9781477250310|url=https://books.google.com/?id=H_A5-RABah4C&pg=PA22&dq=iskander+mirza+martial+law#v=onepage&q=iskander%20mirza%20martial%20law&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=20 December 2012}}{{rp|22}}{{cite web|title=Martial Law Under Field Marshal Ayub Khan Provincial Assemblies were dissolved and all political activities were banned|url=http://storyofpakistan.com/martial-law-under-field-marshal-ayub-khan|website=Story Of Pakistan, Martial law|accessdate=3 November 2016|date=1 June 2003}} In 1960, a [[Elections in Pakistan|referendum]], that functioned as [[Electoral College of Pakistan|Electoral College]], was held that asked the [[Pakistani society|general public:]]''"Do you have confidence in Muhammad Ayub Khan?".'' The voter [[Voter turnout|turnout]] was recorded at 95.6% and such confirmation was used as impetus to formalise the new system– a [[presidential system]]. Ayub Khan was elected president for next five years and decided to pay his first [[State visits to the United States|state visit to United States]] with his wife and also daughter Begum Naseem Aurangzeb in July 1961. Highlights of his visit included a state dinner at [[Mount Vernon]], a visit to the [[Islamic Center of Washington]], and a ticker tape parade in New York City.{{cite web|title=America Welcomes President Ayub|url=http://www.texasarchive.org/library/index.php?title=America_Welcomes_President_Ayub&gsearch=ayub|website=Gordon Wilkison Collection|publisher=Texas Archive of the Moving Image|accessdate=28 July 2011|date=July 1961}} ===Constitutional and legal reforms=== {{further|Constitution of Pakistan of 1962}} [[File:Muhammed Ayub Khan and Alexei Kosygin.jpg|thumb|left|260px|President Ayub Khan meeting [[Russian people|Soviet]] Premier [[Alexei Kosygin]] in 1960s.]] A Constitutional Commission was set-up under the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]] to implement the work on the [[Constitution of Pakistan of 1962|Constitution]] that was led by [[Chief Justice of Pakistan|Chief Justice]] [[Muhammad Shahabuddin]] and [[List of Justices of Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court justices]].{{cite web|last1=Story Of Pakistan, The Constitution of 1962|title=The Constitution of 1962 {{!}} Provided for a unicameral legislature|url=http://storyofpakistan.com/the-constitution-of-1962|website=Story Of Pakistan, The Constitution of 1962|publisher=Story Of Pakistan, The Constitution of 1962|accessdate=3 November 2016|date=1 June 2003}} The Commission reported in 1961 with its recommendations but President Ayub remained unsatisfied; he eventually altered the constitution that was entirely different from the one recommended by the [[Muhammad Shahabuddin|Shahabuddin Commission]]. The Constitution reflected his personal views of politicians and the restriction of using religions in politics. His presidency restored the [[writ]] of government through the [[Constitution of Pakistan of 1962|promulgated constitution]] and restored political freedom by lifting the martial law enforced since 1958. The new Constitution respected [[Islam]] but did not declare Islam as [[state religion]] and was viewed as a liberal constitution. It also provided for election of the President by 80,000 (later raised to 120,000) Basic Democrats who could theoretically make their own choice but who were essentially under his control. He justified this as analogous to the [[Electoral College (United States)|American Electoral College]] and cited [[Thomas Jefferson]] as his inspiration.{{cite book|last1=Jackson|first1=Roy|title=Mawlana Mawdudi and Political Islam: Authority and the Islamic State|publisher=Routledge, Jackson|isbn=9781136950360|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sMotCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA75&dq=Ayub+Khan+thomas+jefferson#v=onepage&q=Ayub%20Khan%20thomas%20jefferson&f=false |page=75 |accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en}} The Ayub administration "guided" the [[Newspapers in Pakistan|print newspapers]] though his takeover of key opposition papers and, while Ayub Khan permitted a [[National Assembly of Pakistan|National Assembly]], it had only limited powers. On 2 March 1961, he passed and signed the "Muslim Family Laws" bill through the [[wikt:ordinance|ordinance]] under which unmitigated [[polygamy]] was abolished, consent of the current wife was made mandatory for a second marriage, brakes were also placed on the practice of instant divorce where men could divorce women by saying:"I divorce you" three times under Islamic tradition.{{cite book|last1=Moghissi|first1=Haideh|title=Women and Islam: Womens's movements in Muslim societies|publisher=Taylor & Francis, Moghissi|isbn=9780415324212|url=https://books.google.com/?id=6ln19FcDV7wC&pg=PA204&dq=Muslim+family+law+ayub#v=onepage&q&f=false |pages=203–204;205 |accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en}} The Arbitration Councils were set up under the law in the urban and rural areas to deal with cases of: (a) grant of sanction to a person to contract a second marriage during the subsistence of a marriage; (b) reconciliation of a dispute between a husband and a wife; (c) grant of a maintenance allowance to the wife and children.{{cite web|url=http://ghazali.net/book1/chapter_4.htm |title=ISLAMIC PAKISTAN: ILLUSIONS & REALITY by Abdul Sattar Ghazali |publisher=Ghazali.net |date= |accessdate=29 April 2010}} ===Economy and infrastructure=== Industrialization and rural development through constructing modern [[National Highways of Pakistan|national freeways]] are considered his greatest achievements and his era is remembered for successful industrialization in the impoverished country. Strong emphasis on capitalism and [[foreign direct investment]] (FDI) in the industry is often regarded as "Great Decade" in the history of the country (both [[Economic history of Pakistan|economical]] and [[Political history of Pakistan|political history]]).{{cite web |url=http://storyofpakistan.com/muhammad-ayub-khan/3 |title=Muhammad Ayub Khan (Part III) |publisher=Story of Pakistan |accessdate=11 February 2012}} The "Great Decade" was celebrated, which highlighted the development plans executed during the years of Ayub's rule, the private consortium companies, industries and credited with creating an environment where the private sector was encouraged to establish medium and small-scale industries in Pakistan. This opened up avenues for new job opportunities and thus the economic graph of the country started rising. He oversaw the development and completion of mega projects such as [[List of dams and reservoirs in Pakistan|hydroelectric dams]], [[List of power stations in Pakistan|power stations]], and [[List of barrages and headworks in Pakistan|barrages]] in all over the country.{{cite book|last1=Mason|first1=Colin|title=A Short History of Asia|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=9781137340610|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VUYdBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA181&dq=Ayub+Khan++hydroelectric+dams#v=onepage&q=Ayub%20Khan%20%20hydroelectric%20dams&f=false|accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=24 June 2014}}{{rp|81}} During 1960–66, the annual GDP growth was recorded at 6.8%.{{cite book|last1=Kukreja|first1=Veena|title=Contemporary Pakistan: Political Processes, Conflicts and Crises|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9780761996835|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gdVNL2_DUtYC&pg=PA304&dq=Ayub+Khan+economy#v=onepage&q=Ayub%20Khan%20economy&f=false |page=304 |accessdate=3 November 2016|language=en|date=24 February 2003}} Several [[energy conservation]] programs were completed such as World's one of the largest dam, the [[Mangla Dam]] and several small dams and [[List of dams and reservoirs in Pakistan|water reservoirs]] in West Pakistan while completing one dam in East Pakistan: [[Kaptai Dam]].{{rp|85}} Plans toward [[Energy in Pakistan|harnessing energy]] from [[Nuclear power|nuclear sources]] were authorized by President Ayub against the wishes of his own administration over the [[Cost of nuclear power|cost]] of [[nuclear power plant]]s.{{rp|54}} Initially, there were two nuclear power plants to be established in the country: one was in [[Karachi Nuclear Power Plant|Karachi]] and the second one in [[Dhaka]].{{rp|54}} It was Dr. [[Abdus Salam]] who had personally approved the [[KANUPP|project in Karachi]] against the wishes of his own government, while the project in East was never materialized.Shahid-ur-Rehman, "Z.A. Bhutto, A Man in Hurry for the Bomb," Long Road To Chagai, p. 21. Extensive education reforms were supposedly carried out and 'scientific development efforts' also supposedly made during his years. These supposed policies could not be sustained after 1965, and the economy collapsed and led to the economic declines which he was unable to control.{{cite web |url=http://storyofpakistan.com/muhammad-ayub-khan/4 |title=Muhammad Ayub Khan (Part IV) |publisher=Story of Pakistan |accessdate=11 February 2012}}[http://www.dawn.com/news/1293604/what-they-never-tell-us-about-ayub-khans-regime Dawn review Aug 2015] He also introduced a new curricula and textbooks for universities and schools after building many public-sector universities and schools were built during his era.{{cite book |last1=Lall |first1=Marie |last2=Vickers |first2=Edward |date=2010 |title=Education as a Political Tool in Asia |publisher=Taylor & Francis |url=https://books.google.com/?id=aAI-G2EuBr0C&pg=PA183 |page=183 |isbn=9780415595360 |accessdate=3 November 2016}} He also introduced [[Agriculture in Pakistan|agricultural reforms]] according to which no one could occupy land less than 12.5 [[acres]] (500 irrigated land and 1000 unirrigated.) An [[Pakistan Refinery|oil refinery]] was established in Karachi, and these reforms led to 15% [[Gross national product|GNP growth]] of the country that was three times greater than that of India. Despite the increase in the [[GNP]] growth, the profit and revenue was gained by the famous [[Oligarchy|22 families]] of the time that controlled 66% of the [[Industry of Pakistan|industries]] and [[Agriculture in Pakistan|land]] of the country and 80% of the [[Banking in Pakistan|banking]] and [[Insurance in Pakistan|insurance]] companies of Pakistan. ===Defence spending=== During his era, the Navy was able to induct submarines and slowly modified itself in terms of acquisitions of warships. However, he drastically reduced funding of military in 1950s and prioritized less on the issue of [[nuclear weapon]]s in 1960s.{{cite book|last1=Khan|first1=Zafar|title=Pakistan's Nuclear Policy: A Minimum Credible Deterrence|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317676010|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XW8KBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA22&dq=ayub+khan+nuclear#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20nuclear&f=false |page=22 |accessdate=4 November 2016|language=en|date=17 July 2014}}{{rp|55}} Major procurement of weapons for the military was relied from the United States's generous donations. Major funding was made available for military acquisitions and procurement towards [[conventional weapon]]ry for [[Conventional warfare|conventional defence]]. In 1960s, Pakistani military had American produced conventional weaponry in terms [[Jeep CJ]], [[M48 Patton]], [[M24 Chaffee]], and [[M16 rifle]]s, [[F-86]], and [[PNS Ghazi|submarine]]– all acquired through [[Foreign Military Sales]] program. In 1961, President Ayub started the nation's full fledge [[Pakistan space program|space program]] that was established with the cooperation of the Air Force, and created civilian [[Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission|Suparco]] that launched [[Chronology of Pakistan's rocket tests|unmanned space missions]] throughout 1960s.{{rp|235–236}} He focused the nuclear issue towards [[Nuclear power|civil power]] and bypassed recommendations towards military-use of [[nuclear technology]] and reportedly spend [[Pakistani rupee|₨.]] 721 million on civil-use of technology in terms of education and nuclear power plants.{{cite book|last1=Khan|first1=Feroz|title=Eating Grass: The Making of the Pakistani Bomb|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=9780804784801|url=https://books.google.com/?id=yGgrNAsKZjEC&pg=PA33&dq=ayub+khan+nuclear+grass#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20nuclear%20grass&f=false|accessdate=4 November 2016|language=en|date=7 November 2012}}{{rp|53}} Finance minister [[Muhammad Shoaib (politician)|Muhammad Shoaib]] argued against spending on nuclear technology and was against of establishing a [[Karachi Nuclear Power Plant|nuclear power plant]] in Karachi over on cost.{{rp|54}} It was Dr. [[Abdus Salam]] who had personally approved the project against the wishes of his own government. After the [[Sino-Indian War of 1962|Sino-Indian war]] in 1962, the military appointments in civilian institutions grew further and defence spending on budget hiked. The physical size of the Pakistan Army's ground troops exponentially grew and the size of military budget grew from 5.79% (1960s) to 9.78% (1966) until being brought down to 6.1% (1967). ===Foreign policy=== ====U.S. alliance and 1960 U-2 incident==== [[File:Motorcade in Arrival Ceremonies for Muhammad Ayub Khan, President of Pakistan use.jpg|thumb|right|225px|President Ayub with [[President Kennedy]] in Washington D.C., [[Circa|ca.]] 1961.]] The [[Pakistan–United States relations|foreign relations]] with the United States and [[European Union]] were prioritized and were main feature of his foreign policy while downplaying [[Pakistan–Soviet Union relations|foreign relations]] with the Soviet Union. While he enjoyed support from President [[Dwight Eisenhower]] in 1950s and convinced the United States alongside with Prime Minister [[Liaquat Ali Khan|Ali Khan]] to forge [[Pakistan–United States military relations|military relations]] in an alliance against regional communism.{{cite web|last=Hussain |first=Hamid |title=Tale of a love affair that never was: United States-Pakistan Defence Relations |url=http://www.defencejournal.com/2002/june/loveaffair.htm |website=MIlitary Consortium of Pakistan |publisher=Military Consortium of Pakistan |accessdate=11 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304115412/http://www.defencejournal.com/2002/june/loveaffair.htm |archivedate=4 March 2012 }} His obsession towards modernization of the [[Pakistan Armed Forces|armed forces]] in shortest time possible saw the relations with United States as the only way to achieve his organization and personal objectives as he argued against [[Civilian control of the military|civilian supremacy]] that would affect the American interests in the region as a result of an election. [[File:President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with President Ayub Khan.jpg|thumb|left|250px|President Ayub receiving President [[Lyndon B. Johnson|Johnson]] in [[Karachi]], [[circa|ca]] 1967.]] Leasing an [[Peshawar Air Station|airbase]] in [[Peshawar]] in 1950s, the [[Central Intelligence Agency]]'s [[CIA activities in Pakistan|spy activities]] grew immensely during his presidency but such activities were exposed in 1960 when the [[USSR|Soviet Union]]'s [[Soviet Air Defence Forces|air defence]] [[1960 U-2 incident|intercept and shot]] down the [[U-2 Dragon Lady|U-2]] plane by the [[S-75 Dvina|S-75]] missile, and captured [[Gary Powers|its pilot]]. This incident severely compromised the [[National Security Council (Pakistan)|national security]] of Pakistan that brought the Soviet ire on Pakistan but President Ayub had all knowledge of the operation and full aware of what happened in the Soviet Union. While in United Kingdom to pay state visit, the [[2010 CIA Station Chief removal in Pakistan|CIA station chief]] told President Ayub who shrugged his shoulders and said that he had expected this would happen at some point. Ayub Khan had to publicly offer his apologies to the Soviet Union after [[Secretary General of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|USSR Secretary General]] [[Nikita Khrushchev]] made a threat to bomb [[Peshawar]].{{rp|43}} President Ayub directed initiatives to [[Foreign Office of Pakistan|Foreign Office]] to reduce tensions with the Soviet Union by facilitating state visits of [[Soviet Premier]] [[Alexei Kosygin]] and [[Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union|Soviet Foreign minister]] [[Andrei Gromyko|Gromyko]] in Pakistan on a condition of downplaying relations with the United States.{{rp|43}} In 1960, he signed the historic [[Sino-Pakistan Frontier Agreement|frontier agreement]] with [[People's Republic of China|China]] despite the US urgings and was a significant event in [[Cold War (1953–62)|history]] of [[Cold war]] where a [[Pakistan|non-communist country]] had entered in alliance with [[People's Republic of China|communist country]].Mitra, Subrata Kumar; Mike Enskat; Clemens Spiess (2004). Political parties in South Asia. Greenwood Publishing Group. p. 157. {{ISBN|0-275-96832-4}}. In 1961–65, Ayub lost much of the support from President [[John F. Kennedy|John Kennedy]] and President [[Lyndon B. Johnson|Lyndon Johnson]] who sought [[Indo-U.S. relations|closer relations]] with India and placed an embargo on [[India and Pakistan|both nations]] during the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|war]] in 1965.{{cite book|last1=Haqqani|first1=Husain|title=Pakistan: Between Mosque and Military|publisher=Carnegie Endowment|isbn=9780870032851|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC&pg=PA44&dq=ayub+khan+foreign+policy#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20foreign%20policy&f=false |pages=44–45 |accessdate=6 November 2016|language=en|date=10 March 2010}} In 1966–67, he wrestled with the United States' dictation on country's foreign policy while strengthening relations with Soviet Union and China, whereas he successfully signed a [[Sino-Pakistan Agreement|border agreement]] to resolve border disputes in 1960s.{{cite book|last1=McGarr|first1=Paul M.|title=The Cold War in South Asia: Britain, the United States and the Indian Subcontinent, 1945–1965|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107292260|url=https://books.google.com/?id=QYkYAAAAQBAJ&pg=RA1-PT286&dq=ayub+khan+china#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=6 November 2016|language=en|date=1 August 2013}} Relations with the Soviet Union were eventually normalized when the Soviets facilitated a [[Tashkent Agreement|peace treaty]] with India in 1965, and reached a trade treaty the following year.{{cite book|last1=Malik|first1=Hafeez|title=Domestic Determinants of Soviet Foreign Policy towards South Asia and the Middle East|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781349113187|url=https://books.google.com/?id=oliwCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA171&dq=ayub+khan+Soviet+union#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20Soviet%20union&f=false|accessdate=6 November 2016|language=en|date=18 June 1990}}{{rp|171–175}} Despite initiatives made towards normalizing with Soviet Union, Ayub Khan remained inclined towards the [[Pro-American|United States]] and [[Pro-western|western world]], having well-received President Johnson in Karachi in 1967.{{rp|174}} In 1961–62, Ayub paid a state visit to the United Kingdom where he garnered a lot of public interests from the [[British society|British public]] when his involvement was revealed in the [[Christine Keeler]] affair.[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/jul/11/scandal-keeler-profumo The Guardian 11 July 2012] Retrieved December 2015[http://www.lrb.co.uk/v29/n01/tariq-ali/the-general-in-his-labyrinth Tariq Ali on Ayub Khan 4 January 2007] Retrieved December 2015 ====India: 1959 joint defence and 1965 war==== {{main|Indo-Pakistani War of 1965}} {{see also|Operation Gibraltar}} In 1959, Ayub Khan's interest in building defence forces already diminished when he made an offer of joint defense with India during the [[Sino-Indian War|Sino-Indo clashes]] in October 1959 in Ladakh, in a move seen as a result of American pressure and a lack of understanding of Foreign affairs{{cite news|last=Iqbal Ahmad Khan|title=Bhutto's foreign policy legacy|url=http://archives.dawn.com/archives/31374|accessdate=11 February 2012|newspaper=Dawn News Papers, 5 April 2009|date=5 April 2009}} Upon hearing this proposal, India's [[Indian Prime Minister|Prime Minister]] [[Jawaharlal Nehru|Nehru]] reportedly counter-ask "Defence Minister Ayub: Joint Defence on what?."{{Rp|84–86}} India remained uninterested with such proposal and Prime Minister Nehru decided to [[India and the Non-Aligned Movement|push his country's role]] in the [[Non-Aligned Movement]]{{Rp|85}} In 1960, President Ayub signed the [[Indus Waters Treaty|water treaty]] with Prime Minister Nehru that was facilitated by the [[World Bank]] as its witness.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/jun/03/kashmir.india1 War over water] The Guardian, Monday 3 June 2002 01.06 BST In 1964, the Pakistan Army engaged with [[Indian Army]] in several [[Indo-Pakistani wars and conflicts|skirmishes]], and a secretive operations began to place around that time. The [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|war]] with India in 1965 was a turning point in his presidency, and it ended in a settlement reached by Ayub Khan at Tashkent, called the [[Tashkent Declaration]], which was facilitated by the Soviet Union. The settlement was perceived negatively by many Pakistanis and led [[Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto]] to resign his post and take up opposition to Ayub Khan. According to Morrice James, "For them [Pakistanis] Ayub had betrayed the nation and had inexcusably lost face before the Indians."''Kashmir in Conflict: India, Pakistan and the Unending War'' by Victoria Schofield Published 2003, by I.B.Tauris {{ISBN|1-86064-898-3}} p. 112. According to [[Sartaj Aziz]], it was [[Foreign Minister of Pakistan|Foreign Minister]] Bhutto that had gone on a populist [[Indophobia in Pakistan|Anti-Indian]] and [[Anti-American sentiment in Pakistan|Anti-American]] binge during the meeting in a cabinet meeting with President Ayub.{{cite news|last=Ahmed |first=Khaled |date=9 August 2009 |title=Book Review: Sartaj Aziz on 'excessive' leaders |url=http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/editorial/09-Aug-2009/book-review-sartaj-aziz-on-excessive-leaders-by-khaled-ahmed |newspaper=Pakistan Times |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304063953/http://archives.dailytimes.com.pk/editorial/09-Aug-2009/book-review-sartaj-aziz-on-excessive-leaders-by-khaled-ahmed |archivedate=4 March 2016 }} Bhutto succeeded in the meeting on spellbinding the ruling President into thinking he was becoming a world statesman fawned upon by the [[Axis of evil|enemies]] of the United States. When authorizing the ''Operation Gibraltar'', [[Deputy Chairman]] of [[Planning Commission (Pakistan)|Planning Commission]] had famously told the President in the meeting: "Sir, I hope you realize that our foreign policy and our economic requirements are not fully consistent, in fact they are rapidly falling out of line". Aziz vetoed the ''Operation Gibraltar'' against India, fearing the economical turmoil that would jolt the country's economy, but was rebuffed by his senior bureaucrats. In that meeting, Foreign Minister Bhutto convinced the President and the Finance Minister [[Muhammad Shoaib (politician)|Muhammad Shoaib]] that India would not attack Pakistan due to [[Kashmir]] being a [[Kashmir dispute|disputed territory]], and per Bhutto's remarks: "Pakistan’s incursion into [[Indian-occupied Kashmir]], at [A]khnoor, would not provide [India] with the justification for attacking Pakistan across the international boundary because Kashmir was a disputed territory". This theory proved wrong when India launched a full-scale war against [[West Pakistan|West-Pakistan]] in 1965. His [[Chief of Army Staff (Pakistan)|army chief]] General [[Musa Khan]] did not order the Pakistan Army without the confirmation by President Ayub Khan despite Foreign Minister [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto|Bhutto's]] urging {{rp|182–183}} However, after the [[Indian Army]] advanced towards the [[Rann of Kutch]], General Musa Khan ordered the army to respond against the opposing force.{{rp|183}} He faced serious altercations and public criticism with [[Commander in Chief (Pakistan Air Force)|air chief]] [[Air Marshal|AM]] [[Asghar Khan]] for hiding the details of the war.{{cite news|last1=Editorial publication|title=Nur Khan reminisces ’65 war|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/155474/nur-khan-reminisces|accessdate=31 October 2016|work=DAWN.COM|publisher=Dawn newspapers, Editorial|date=6 September 2005}} The [[AHQ (Pakistan Air Force)|Air AHQ]] began fighting the president over the contingency plans, and this inter-services rivalry ended with Asghar Khan's resignation. To reduce interservices tensions and criticism, [[Chief of Naval Staff (Pakistan)|navy commander]] Admiral [[Afzal Rahman Khan|A.R. Khan]] authorised the [[Operation Dwarka|shelling operation]] against [[Indian Navy]] posts in shores of [[Dwarka]], India.{{rp|25}} About the 1965 war's contingency plans, AM [[Nur Khan]] briefly wrote that "Rumours about an impending operation were rife but the army had not shared the plans with other forces." Ayub Khan's main sponsor, the United States, did not welcome the move and the [[Kennedy administration]] placed an economic embargo that caused Pakistan to lose [[United States dollar|$]]500 million in [[Foreign aid to Pakistan|aid and grants]] that had been received through consortium. Ayub Khan could not politically survive in the aftermath of 1965 war with India and fell from the presidency after surrendering the presidential power to [[Army Chief of Staff (Pakistan)|Army Commander]] General [[Yahya Khan|Yahya]] in 1969. ==End of Presidency== === Presidential election of 1965 === {{main|Pakistani presidential election, 1965}} In 1964, President Ayub Khan had been confident in his apparent popularity and saw the deep divisions within the political opposition which ultimately led him to announce the [[Elections in Pakistan|presidential elections]] in 1965.{{cite web|title=Presidential Election {{!}} Elections were held on 2 January 1965|url=http://storyofpakistan.com/presidential-election#prettyPhoto|website=Story Of Pakistan|publisher=Story Of Pakistan, Elections 1965|accessdate=4 November 2016|date=25 October 2013}} He earned the nomination from [[Pakistan Muslim League]] (PML) and was shocked to see when [[Fatima Jinnah]] earned the nomination from the [[Movement for the Restoration of Democracy|Combined Opposition Parties]]. Fatima Jinnah had gained a lot of support from Karachi, [[Lahore]], and various parts in West Pakistan and East Pakistan as opposed to President Ayub Khan. Jinnah targeted the [[Indus Waters Treaty]] and his over-reliance on the United States and troubled relations with the Soviet Union. During the elections, President Ayub earned notoriety when his son, [[Gohar Ayub Khan]], was named in media for his involvement in authorizing political murders in Karachi, particularly those who supported Jinnah.{{cite book|last1=Goulbourne|first1=Harry|title=Race and Ethnicity: Solidarities and communities|date=2001|publisher=Taylor & Francis|location=London [u.a.]|isbn=9780415225014|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WIg_9GI9a8gC&pg=PA232&dq=Ayub+Khan++karachi+1965+elections#v=onepage&q=Ayub%20Khan%20%20karachi%201965%20elections&f=false |page=232 |language=en}} Angry protesters took their demonstrations in streets in [[Sindh]] and slogans were chanted against President Ayub. Fatima Jinnah won the landslide voting but Ayub Khan won the elections through the Electoral College.{{cite book|last1=Riches|first1=Christopher|last2=Palmowski|first2=Jan|title=A Dictionary of Contemporary World History|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780191060762|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KBI1DQAAQBAJ&pg=PT1194&dq=Fatima+Jinnah+1965+elections#v=onepage&q=Fatima%20Jinnah%201965%20elections&f=false |page=xxx |accessdate=4 November 2016|language=en|date=15 September 2016}} During this time, Ayub Khan exploited the [[Pakistani Intelligence Community|intelligence community]] to tape politicians telephone and monitor their gatherings for his own advantage. For that purpose, the [[Military Intelligence (Pakistan)|Military Intelligence]] became extremely active during the presidential elections keeping politicians in mass surveillance and while [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Intelligence Bureau]] taped telephone recordings rather than keeping their work nation's defence and security.{{cite web|last1=Pike|first1=John|title=Military Intelligence – Pakistan Intelligence Agencies|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/intell/world/pakistan/mi.htm|website=www.globalsecurity.org|publisher=global security|accessdate=5 November 2016}} This was the first time in the nation's history that intelligence community had directly interfered in the [[Politics of Pakistan|national politics]], and intelligence community continued this role in successive years. It was reported that the elections were widely [[Vote rigging|rigged]] by the state authorities and machinery under the control of Ayub Khan and it is believed that had the elections been held via direct ballot, Fatima Jinnah would have won. The Electoral College consisted of only 80,000 Basic Democrats, who were easily manipulated by President Ayub Khan and bitterly won the elections with 64%.{{cite news|author=|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,830952,00.html |title=Trouble with Mother |publisher=Time.com |date=25 December 1964 |accessdate=29 April 2010}} The election did not conform to international standards per many journalists of the time and many saw the results with great suspicions. === 1969 nationwide riots and resignation === {{Main|Agartala Conspiracy Case}} {{See also|Six point movement}} The controversial winning over [[Fatima Jinnah]] in [[Pakistani presidential election, 1965|presidential elections]] and the outcomes of [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|war]] with India in 1965 brought devastating results for Ayub Khan's image and his presidency.{{cite book|last1=Abbas|first1=Hassan|title=Pakistan's Drift Into Extremism: Allah, the Army, and America's War on Terror|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=9780765631718|url=https://books.google.com/?id=GbgoBGFSMRQC&pg=PA52&dq=ayub+khan+1965+war#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%201965%20war&f=false |pages=52–53 |accessdate=4 November 2016|language=en|date=1 September 2004}} Upon returning from [[Tashkent]], Foreign Minister [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto|Bhutto]] went to the [[Media of Pakistan|television media]] and criticized President Ayub for selling nation's honor and sacrifice which promoted President Ayub to deposed Bhutto. In [[Karachi]], the public resentment towards Ayub had been rising since the 1965 elections and his policies were widely disapproved.{{cite book|last1=Rath|first1=Saroj Kumar|title=Fragile Frontiers: The Secret History of Mumbai Terror Attacks|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317562511|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Dh7ICQAAQBAJ&pg=PT51&dq=ayub+khan+tashkent+agreement#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20tashkent%20agreement&f=false|accessdate=4 November 2016|language=en|date=3 June 2015}} In 1967, [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] formed the socialist [[Pakistan Peoples Party]] and attacked Ayub administration's economic, religious, and social policy while taking the nationwide tour.{{rp|196}} Detention of Bhutto further inflamed the opposition and demonstration sparked in all over the country with East Pakistani Awami League charging Ayub administration of [[Geographical segregation|segregating policies]] towards East.{{cite book |last1=Wynbrandt |first1=James |date=2009 |title=A Brief History of Pakistan |url=https://books.google.com/?id=xQGwgJnCPZgC&pg=PA196 |publisher=Infobase Publishing |page=196 |isbn=9780816061846 |accessdate=4 November 2016}}{{rp|197}} [[List of trade unions in Pakistan|Labour unions]] called for labour strikes against Ayub Khan's labour legislation and dissatisfaction was widespread in the country from country's middle class by the end of 1968.{{rp|198}} When the Ayub Khan was presented with the [[Six point movement|Six points]] by [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman|Rahman]] and Bhutto's called for disapproving Ayub; he responded by imprisoning both leaders but that made matters worst for Ayub's administration.{{rp|198}} [[Socialism in Pakistan|Left-wing]] parties, allied with the [[Conservatism in Pakistan|conservative mass]], began advocating for the [[Islam in Pakistan|Islamic]] [[parliamentary democracy]] system against his presidential rule. In 1968, he survived a failed assassination attempt while visiting [[Dacca]] and was visibly shaken after this attempt, according to the close aides; though this was not reported in the press of the day.{{cite book | author=Hassan Abbas | title=Pakistan's Drift Into Extremism: Allah, the Army, and America's War on Terror | publisher=M. E. Sharpe | year=2004|isbn=978-0-7656-1497-1}}, p. 53. In 1969, Ayub Khan opened up the negotiations with the opposition parties in what was termed as "[[Round table (discussion)|Round Table Conference]]" where he held talks with every opposition party except for [[Awami League]] and [[Pakistan Peoples Party]].{{rp|198}} However, no results were yielded and strong anti-Ayub demonstration sparked in all over the country that called for his resignation.{{rp|198}} During this time, Ayub Khan survived a near-fatal [[Heart attack|cardiac arrest]] that put him out of the office, and later survived a [[paralysis]] attack that put him on [[wheelchair]].{{cite book|last1=Akbar|first1=M. K.|title=Pakistan from Jinnah to Sharif|publisher=Mittal Publications|isbn=9788170996743|url=https://books.google.com/?id=BcIniHQAHfUC&pg=PA37&dq=ayub+khan+1965+war#v=onepage&q&f=false |pages=43–47 |accessdate=4 November 2016|language=en}} The [[Police Service of Pakistan|Police]] were unable to control the situation and the [[Law and order in Pakistan|law and order]] situation worsen in the country, especially in East where the serious [[1969 uprising in East Pakistan|uprising and riots]] were quelled in 1969, that at one point, his [[Interior Minister of Pakistan|Home]] and [[Defence Minister of Pakistan|Defence Minister]] Vice-Admiral Rahman told the journalists that the "country was under the Mob rule and that Police were not strong enough to tackle the situation".{{cite book|last1=Siddiqui|first1=Kalim|title=Conflict, Crisis and War in Pakistan|publisher=Springer, Siddiqui|isbn=9781349013395|url=https://books.google.com/?id=f86uCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA130&dq=AR+Khan+minister+resigned#v=onepage&q=AR%20Khan%20minister%20resigned&f=false |page=130 |accessdate=1 November 2016|language=en}} The [[Pakistan Peoples Party|PPP]] also led very strong protests, street demonstrations, and riots against the Ayub Khan's administration when the prices of food consumer products such as sugar, tea, and wheat, hiked up and eventually people widely disapproved of Ayub Khan by chanting slogans and employing insults on referring to Ayub in 1969.{{cite book|last1=Constable|first1=Pamela|title=Playing with Fire: Pakistan at War with Itself|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|isbn=9780679603450|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Y-wU1aVyM9IC&pg=PA39&dq=ayub+khan+price+hike#v=onepage&q=ayub%20khan%20price%20hike&f=false|accessdate=4 November 2016|language=en|date=19 July 2011}}{{rp|39–40}} On the streets of major cities of West Pakistan, there were massive [[Graffiti|wall chalking]] that were identified as [[Derogatory term|derogatory]] and [[pejorative]] terms employed on Ayub and his image that made [[headline]]s in the [[Newspapers in Pakistan|print]] and [[News channels in Pakistan|electronic media]].{{rp|41}} Ayub Khan, himself, was shocked when hearing the young protesters and college students in [[West Pakistan|West]] had been referring him to as "Dog".
