{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} The '''Kennedy curse''' is a term for a series of deaths and calamities involving members of the [[Americans|American]] [[Kennedy family]].<ref name=WP>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/longterm/jfkjr/timeline.htm|title=Kennedy Family Tragedies|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=August 26, 2009|date=July 18, 1999}}</ref><ref name=tribune>{{cite news |first1= Pat |last1= Carr |first2= Lee |last2= Hulteng |url= http://www.courant.com/news/politics/20090826_tragedies_kennedy,0,5261652.graphic |title= Kennedy Family Tragedies |work= [[The Hartford Courant|The Courant]] |location= Hartford, CT |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name=boston>{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/packages/jfkjr/mcgrory.htm |title= Family Overshadowed by a Litany of Tragedy |work= [[The Boston Globe]] |last=McGrory |first= Brian|date=July 18, 1999|accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name=boston/><ref name=klein>{{cite book |title= The Kennedy Curse: Why Tragedy Has Haunted America's First Family for 150 Years |last= Klein |first= Edward |authorlink= Edward Klein |year= 2004 |publisher= [[St. Martin's Press]] |isbn=978-0-312-31293-0}}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/aug/26/kennedy-curse-senator-ted-death |title=History of the Kennedy Curse |work= [[The Guardian]] |date= August 26, 2009 |last1= Jones |first1= Sam |last2= Tran |first2= Mark |accessdate= August 26, 2009 |location= London}}</ref><ref name=hartford>{{cite web|url=http://www.courant.com/news/politics/hc-kennedy-curse-pictures,0,1958578.photogallery|title=The Kennedy Curse|work= The Courant |location= Hartford, CT |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name=abc>{{cite news |url= http://www.abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=1926999 |title= Is Pat's Crash Part of Kennedy Curse? |work= [[Good Morning America]] |publisher= [[ABC News]] |date= May 5, 2006 |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,1918758,00.html?cnn=yes |title= Ted Kennedy, 1932–2009: The Brother Who Mattered Most |work= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |last= Lacayo |first= Richard |date= August 26, 2009 |accessdate= August 26, 2009}}</ref> [[Ted Kennedy]] publicly wondered whether a "curse actually did hang over all the Kennedys" during his own testimony about the [[Chappaquiddick incident]] in 1969.{{r|time19680801}} However, skeptics argue that many of the events are normal, and that it is not improbable for a large extended family to experience them.<ref name="skeptic">{{cite web |last= |first= |title= Kennedy Curse |work= [[The Skeptic's Dictionary]] |url= http://www.skepdic.com/kennedycurse.html |accessdate= August 29, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.irishcentral.com/story/news/periscope/talk-of-a-kennedy-curse-is-nonsense-latest-death-of-kara-revives-idle-chatter-130061473.html |title= Talk of a Kennedy Curse Is Nonsense, Latest Death of Kara Revives Idle Chatter |work= IrishCentral |last= O'Dowd |first= Niall |authorlink= Niall O'Dowd |date= September 18, 2011 |accessdate= May 19, 2012}}</ref>
==Chronology== Events that have been cited as evidence of the family's misfortunes include:
<!--Do **not** add Ted Kennedy (died at 77), Eunice Kennedy (88), or anyone else who died from a non-unusual reason (cancer is not unusual) or at a non-unusual age or without a source calling it part of the Kennedy Tragedy/Curse. Discuss at Talk.--> * 1941 — [[Rosemary Kennedy]] was often believed to have been [[Intellectual disability|intellectually disabled]], and due to her severe mood swings and the worry that she would damage the Kennedy reputation,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/the-exiled-kennedy-486688.html |title=The exiled Kennedy |last=El-Hai |first=Jack |date=January 15, 2005 |website=The Independent |publisher=Independent Print Limited |access-date=September 4, 2017 |quote=}}</ref> her father, [[Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.|Joseph Sr.]], arranged in secret for her to undergo a [[lobotomy]]. The lobotomy instead left her unable to walk or speak well, and as a result, Rosemary remained [[Psychiatric hospital|institutionalized]] until her death in 2005.<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="cnn-king">{{cite news |title= Tragedy Has Repeatedly Stalked Kennedy Clan |first= John |last= King |authorlink= John King (journalist) |publisher= CNN |date= July 17, 1999 |accessdate= February 15, 2008 |url= http://edition.cnn.com/US/9907/17/kennedy.tragedies/}}</ref><ref name="abc2012"/> Rosemary's condition may have inspired her sister, [[Eunice Kennedy Shriver|Eunice]], to initiate the [[Special Olympics]] in 1962. * August 12, 1944 — [[Joseph P. Kennedy Jr.]] died when his plane exploded over [[East Suffolk (county)|East Suffolk]], England, as part of [[Operation Aphrodite|Project Anvil]] during [[World War II]]. * May 13, 1948 — [[Kathleen Cavendish, Marchioness of Hartington]] died in a plane crash in [[France]].<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="abc2012"/> * August 9, 1963 — [[Patrick Bouvier Kennedy]] died of [[infant respiratory distress syndrome]] two days after his premature birth (which itself occurred on the 20th anniversary of his father's World War II rescue). Jackie missed the funeral because she was still recovering from the C-section at [[Otis Air National Guard Base|Otis Air Force Base]].<ref name=klein/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="cnn-king" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/for-john-and-jackie-kennedy-the-death-of-a-son-may-have-brought-them-closer/2013/10/24/2506051e-369b-11e3-ae46-e4248e75c8ea_story.html|title=For John and Jackie Kennedy, the death of a son may have brought them closer|last=Levingston|first=Steven|date=October 24, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=June 2, 2016}}</ref> * November 22, 1963 — [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[John F. Kennedy]] [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|was assassinated]] in [[Dallas|Dallas, Texas]] by [[Lee Harvey Oswald]]. Oswald was shot dead by [[Jack Ruby]] two days later before he could stand trial. In 1964, the [[Warren Commission]] concluded that Oswald was the lone assassin. In 1979, the [[United States House Select Committee on Assassinations]] (HSCA) concluded that the assassination was the result of a conspiracy and that Oswald did not act alone.<ref>{{cite web |first=Louis |last=Stokes|authorlink=Louis Stokes|title=Report of the Select Committee on Assassinations of the U.S. House of Representatives|year=1979|publisher=United States Government Printing Office |location=Washington, D.C. |url=https://www.archives.gov/research/jfk/select-committee-report/}} </ref> * June 19, 1964 — [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Ted Kennedy]] was involved in a plane crash in which one of his aides and the pilot were killed. Ted was pulled from the wreckage by fellow senator [[Birch Bayh]] and spent weeks in a hospital recovering from a broken back, a punctured lung, broken ribs, and internal bleeding.<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name="abc2012"/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.check-six.com/Crash_Sites/Kennedy-N344S.htm |publisher= Check-Six.com |title= The Luck of the Kennedys |accessdate= May 1, 2012 |date= May 8, 2008}}</ref> * June 5, 1968 — U.S. Senator [[Robert F. Kennedy]] [[Assassination of Robert F. Kennedy|was assassinated]] by [[Sirhan Sirhan]] in [[Los Angeles]] immediately following his victory in the California [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 1968|Democratic presidential primary]]. Sirhan pleaded guilty to Robert's murder and is serving a life sentence at the [[Richard J. Donovan Correctional Facility]].<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="abc2012"/> * July 18, 1969 — In the [[Chappaquiddick incident]], Ted Kennedy accidentally drove his car off a bridge on [[Chappaquiddick Island]], which fatally trapped his 28-year-old passenger, [[Mary Jo Kopechne]], inside.<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name=abc/><ref name="abc2012"/> Ted pleaded guilty to a charge of leaving the scene of the accident causing personal injury.<ref>Russell, Jenna (February 17, 2009). "Chapter 3: Chappaquiddick: Conflicted ambitions, then, Chappaquiddick". The Boston Globe. Archived from the original on February 21, 2010.Also published in the book The Last Lion: The Fall and Rise of Ted Kennedy, Simon & Schuster, 2009, chapter 3.</ref> In his televised statement a week later, Ted stated that on the night of the incident he wondered "whether some awful curse did actually hang over all the Kennedys."<ref name="time19680801">{{Cite magazine|date=August 1, 1969 |title=The Mysteries of Chappaquiddick |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,901159-1,00.html |magazine=Time |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831015242/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0%2C9171%2C901159-1%2C00.html |archive-date=August 31, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title= 'Grief, Fear, Doubt, Panic' — And Guilt |work= [[Newsweek]] |date= August 4, 1969 <!--|accessdate=August 26, 2009-->}}</ref><ref>{{cite video |last= Kennedy |first= Ted |title= The Kennedys |medium= TV-series |work= [[American Experience]] |station= [[WGBH-TV]] |location= Boston |network= [[PBS]] |url= https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/kennedys/ |year= 2009 }}</ref> * August 13, 1973 — [[Joseph P. Kennedy II]] was the driver of a [[Jeep]] that crashed and left his passenger, Pam Kelley, paralyzed.<ref name=klein/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="cnn-king" /> * April 25, 1984 — [[David A. Kennedy]] died of a [[cocaine]] and [[pethidine]] overdose in a [[Palm Beach, Florida]] hotel room.<ref name="klein" /><ref name="guardian" /><ref name="hartford" /><ref name="cnn-king" /><ref name="abc2012" /> * April 1, 1991 — [[William Kennedy Smith]] was arrested and charged with the rape of a young woman at the Kennedy estate in Palm Beach, Florida. The subsequent trial attracted extensive media coverage.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/archive/1992/03/dunne199203 |title= The Verdict |last= Dunne |first= Dominick |authorlink= Dominick Dunne |date= March 1992 |work= [[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> Smith was acquitted.<ref name=WP/><ref name=boston/><ref name=klein/><ref name="cnn-king"/> * December 31, 1997 — [[Michael LeMoyne Kennedy]] died in a skiing accident in [[Aspen, Colorado]].<ref name=WP/><ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="cnn-king" /><ref name="abc2012"/> * July 16, 1999 — [[John F. Kennedy Jr.]] [[John F. Kennedy Jr. plane crash|died]] when his plane he was piloting, a [[Piper PA-32R|Piper Saratoga]], crashed into the [[Atlantic Ocean]] off the coast of [[Martha's Vineyard]] due to [[pilot error]] and [[spatial disorientation]]. [[Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy|His wife]] and sister-in-law were also on board and died.<ref name=klein/><ref name=guardian/><ref name=hartford/><ref name="abc2012"/> * September 16, 2011 — [[Kara Kennedy]] died of a heart attack while exercising in a [[Washington, D.C.]] health club at age 51. Kara had reportedly suffered from lung cancer nine years earlier, but she had recovered after the removal of part of her right lung.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8771095/Kara-Kennedy-dies-aged-51.html |title= Kara Kennedy Dies Aged 51 |work= [[The Daily Telegraph]] |last= Goddard |first= Jacqui |date= September 17, 2011 |accessdate= May 19, 2012 |location= London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2039733/Kara-Kennedy-Lung-cancer-cure-caused-heart-attack.html |title= 'I'm So Grateful I Have Those Memories': Joan Kennedy Remembers Last Summer with Daughter Kara Before She Died |work= [[The Daily Mail]] |date= September 21, 2011 |accessdate= May 19, 2012 |location= London}}</ref> * May 16, 2012 — [[Robert F. Kennedy, Jr.#Marriages and children|Mary Richardson Kennedy]] committed suicide on the grounds of her home in Bedford, [[Westchester County, New York]].<ref name="abc2012">{{cite web |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/OTUS/kennedy-curse-political-familys-troubled-life/story?id=16362763 |title=Kennedy Curse: A Political Family's Troubled Life |publisher= ABC News |date= May 16, 2012 |last=Negrin |first= Matt |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jsfT2VoGbAR2P9uBoMOiCBb6817g?docId=788fa9391b1f42e993f59fe3312a837b |title= RFK Jr.'s Troubled Estranged Wife Found Dead in NY |work= Google News |agency= [[Associated Press]] |date= May 16, 2012 |accessdate= May 16, 2012}}</ref> * September 4, 2018 — [[Christopher Kennedy Lawford]] died of a heart attack while doing hot yoga at a yoga studio in [[Vancouver, British Columbia]]. He was 63.
==Biographies== *''The Kennedy Curse: Why Tragedy Has Haunted America's First Family for 150 Years'' by Edward Klein, was published by St. Martin's Press.<Ref>[http://us.macmillan.com/books/9780312312930 The Kennedy Curse]</ref> *''The Kennedy Curse: Shattered'', a compilation of Kennedy curse accounts by Les Williams, was published in 9 November 2016 by Gayles Publishing.<Ref>[http://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/books/803899/kennedy-curse-book-jfk-assassination-america-family-joe-mystery The Kennedy Curse busted: It was ALL Joe Kennedy’s fault and here's WHY]</ref><ref>[https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/kennedy-curse-shattered-les-williams The Kennedy Curse: Shattered]</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{Portal|Anglicanism}} '''Lesser Festivals''' are a type of observance in the [[Anglican Communion]], including the [[Church of England]], considered to be less significant than a [[Principal Feast]], [[Principal Holy Day]], or [[Festival (Church of England)|Festival]], but more significant than a [[Commemoration (observance)|Commemoration]]. Whereas Principal Feasts must be celebrated, it is not obligatory to observe Lesser Festivals. They are always attached to a calendar date, and are not observed if they fall on a Sunday, in [[Holy Week]], or in [[Octave of Easter|Easter Week]]. In ''[[Common Worship]]'' each Lesser Festival is provided with a [[collect]] and an indication of [[liturgical colour]].
==Lesser Festivals in the Church of England== ''Source: C of E website.''<ref>{{Cite web|title=Lesser Festivals|url=https://www.churchofengland.org/prayer-worship/worship/texts/festivals/lesser-festivals.aspx|accessdate=27 October 2016|publisher=Church of England|}}</ref> ===January=== *2 January: [[Basil of Caesarea|Basil the Great]] and [[Gregory of Nazianzus]], [[Bishop]]s, Teachers of the Faith, 379 and 389 *12 January: [[Aelred of Hexham]], [[Abbot of Rievaulx]], 1167 *13 January: [[Hilary of Poitiers|Hilary]], [[Bishop of Poitiers]], Teacher of the Faith, 367 *17 January: [[Antony of Egypt]], [[Hermit]], [[Abbot]], 356 *19 January: [[Saint Wulfstan|Wulfstan]], [[Bishop of Worcester]], 1095 *21 January: [[Saint Agnes|Agnes]], Child Martyr at [[Rome]], 304 *24 January: [[Francis de Sales]], [[Bishop of Geneva]], Teacher of the Faith, 1622 *26 January: [[Saint Timothy|Timothy]] and [[Apostle Titus|Titus]], Companions of [[Paul of Tarsus|Paul]] *28 January: [[Thomas Aquinas]], Priest, Philosopher, Teacher of the Faith, 1274 *30 January: [[Charles I of England|Charles]], King and Martyr, 1649
===February=== *3 February: [[Ansgar|Anskar]], [[Archbishop of Hamburg]], Missionary in Denmark and Sweden, 865 *14 February: [[Saints Cyril and Methodius|Cyril and Methodius]], Missionaries to the Slavs, 869 and 885 *17 February: [[Janani Luwum]], [[Archbishop]] of [[Church of Uganda|Uganda]], [[Martyr]], 1977 *23 February: [[Polycarp]], Bishop of [[Smyrna]], Martyr, c 155 *27 February: [[George Herbert]], Priest, Poet, 1633
===Other examples=== *17 March: [[Saint Patrick|Patrick]], Bishop, [[Missionary]], [[Patron saint|Patron]] of [[Ireland]], c 460 *10 April: [[William Law]], [[Priest]], Spiritual Writer, 1761 *20 May: [[Alcuin|Alcuin of York]], [[Deacon]], [[Abbot]] of [[Tours]], 804 *30 May: [[Josephine Butler]], [[social reform]]er, 1906 *16 June: [[Richard of Chichester|Richard]], [[Bishop of Chichester]], 1253 *11 July: [[Benedict of Nursia]], Abbot of [[Monte Cassino]], Father of Western [[Monk|Monasticism]], c 550 *20 August: [[Bernard of Clairvaux|Bernard]], Abbot of [[Clairvaux Abbey|Clairvaux]], Teacher of the Faith, 1153 *13 September: [[John Chrysostom]], [[Bishop of Constantinople]], Teacher of the Faith, 407 *25 September: [[Lancelot Andrewes]], overseer of the [[King James Version of the Bible]] *4 October: [[Francis of Assisi]], [[Friar]], Deacon, Founder of the [[Friars Minor]], 1226 *26 October: [[Alfred the Great]], King of the [[Wessex|West Saxons]], Scholar, 899 *20 November: [[Edmund the Martyr|Edmund]], [[Monarch|King]] of the [[East Anglia|East Angles]], Martyr, 870 *13 December: [[Saint Lucy|Lucy]], Martyr at [[Syracuse, Sicily|Syracuse]], 304

page.title: List of incidents of violence against women in Spain

revision.text:
This is a '''list of incidents of violence against women in Spain'''. The [[Ministry of Health (Spain)|Ministry of Health, Social Services and Equality]] publishes statistics on [[violence against women]] and counts every death. Also, [[media in Spain]] reports every case of violence against women that results in a death.
In the last decade about 700 women have been killed in Spain by their partners or ex-partners.<ref>{{cite web|title=700 mujeres muertas por violencia de género en la última década|url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2013/11/03/52766e7363fd3d62298b456e.html|publisher=El Mundo|date=2013-11-03|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> Since 1999, the number of killed women is over 1,000.
{{Expand list|date=April 2018}}
== Before 2003 == * November 13, 1992: [[Alcasser Girls]]: 3 teenage girls from Alcàsser, Valencia, Spain, who were kidnapped, raped, assaulted and murdered after hitchhiking to get to a nightclub. * April 1993: [[Kidnapping of Anabel Segura]]: 2 men kidnap and later (whe she was trying to escape) murder a 22 year old woman.<ref>[https://elpais.com/diario/1993/04/16/madrid/734959454_850215.html El padre de Ia secuestrada en La Moraleja dirige una empresa de ingeniería] in [[El País]]</ref> * December 17, 1997: [[Ana Orantes]]: After her testimony shown on a television program, she was killed by her last husband.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sánchez Hidalgo |first=Emilio |title=Recordando a Ana Orantes, cuyo testimonio cambió la visión de la violencia machista |url=https://verne.elpais.com/verne/2017/09/30/articulo/1506779392_536978.html |date=September 30, 2017 |access-date=November 27, 2017 |newspaper=[[El País]] |agency=Verne |language=es}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=El Khattat |first=Mohamed |title=Un hombre mata a su ex mujer prendiéndole fuego tras atarla |url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/1997/diciembre/18/nacional/malostratos.html |date=November 18, 1997 |access-date=September 30, 2017 |newspaper=[[ABC (Spain)|ABC]] |location=Granada |language=es}}</ref> It caused a big repercussion about gender violence, and as a consequence, the restructuring of the [[Criminal Code of Spain]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=E. Ramírez |first=Carlota |title=El asesinato de Ana Orantes: un antes y un después en la violencia machista en España |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.es/2017/11/17/el-asesinato-de-ana-orantes-un-antes-y-un-despues-en-la-violencia-machista-en-espana_a_23280596/ |date=November 17, 2017 |access-date=November 27, 2017 |newspaper=[[Huffington Post]] |language=es}}</ref> * April 20, 1997: [[Murder of Eva Blanco]]: Spanish high school student who was murdered in Algete, Community of Madrid. The case remained unsolved until 2015 * October 9/10, 1999: [[Murder of Rocío Wanninkhof]]: a Dutch-Spanish teenage girl who was murdered in her hometown of Mijas
== 2003 - 2011 == *Women killed in [[gender violence]] cases **2003: 71 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/DatosViolenciaGeneroAno2003.pdf Official data] of [[Ministry of Health (Spain)|Ministry of Health]] website {{es}}</ref> **2004: 72 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/Datos_violencia_genero_ano_2004.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2005: 57 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/Datos_violencia_genero_ano_2005.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2006: 69 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/Datos_violencia_genero_ano_2006.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2007: 71 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/Datos_violencia_genero_ano_2007.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2008: 76 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/Datos_violencia_genero_ano_2008.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2009: 56 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/Datos_violencia_genero_ano_2009.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2010: 73 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/Datos_violencia_genero_ano_2010.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2011: 62 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/mortales/docs/2011.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> * 17 May 2003: [[Murder of Sandra Palo]]: A woman (22) is raped, run over by a car and burnt alive by 4 minors (in the 14-18 age range) in Madrid.<ref>[http://www.lavanguardia.com/sucesos/20180518/443637789090/sandra-palo-asesino-rafita-rafael-fernandez-garcia-menor-crimen-quince-anos-las-caras-del-mal.html ‘El Rafita’, el menor que violó, quemó y asesinó a Sandra Palo] in lavanguardia.com {{es}}</ref> * 24 January 2009: [[Murder of Marta del Castillo]]: a Spanish high school student who disappeared and was presumably murdered * 14 August 2009: Murder of Sonia Carabantes: Murder of a 17 year old girl that helped to solve the case of [[Murder of Rocío Wanninkhof|Rocío Wanninkhof]]
== 2012- 2014 == *Women killed in gender violence cases: **2012: 52 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/pdf/V_Mortales_2012.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2013: 54 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/pdf/Espana_2013.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> **2014: 55 women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/pdf/2014.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website {{es}}</ref> * June 30, 2012: A man kills and butchers his partner in [[Cadrete]].<ref>[https://www.heraldo.es/noticias/aragon/zaragoza_provincia/zaragoza/2014/08/20/la_familia_descuartizada_cadrete_acusa_tambien_asesinato_dos_cunados_305655_301.html La familia de la descuartizada de Cadrete acusa también de asesinato a dos cuñados] in [[Heraldo de Aragón]].</ref>
== 2015 ==
60 women were killed in Spain in cases of violence against women<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/pdf/VMortales_2015_31-12(5).pdf Official data] of [[Ministry of Health (Spain)|Ministry of Health]] website:</ref>
* January 12: A man (70) kills his ex-partner (70) and her sister (64) in [[Elche]]. Later, he commits suicide. Five minutes of silence were observed for the double crime.<ref>{{cite web|title=El acusado de matar a su exmujer y su excuñada usó una barra de hierro y dejó una nota autoinculpatoria|url=http://www.lasprovincias.es/sucesos/201501/13/acusado-matar-exmujer-excunada-20150113120021.html|publisher=Las Provincias|date=2015-01-13|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Un hombre mata a su ex pareja y a la hermana de ésta y luego se ahorca en Elche|url=http://www.publico.es/sociedad/sucesos/hombre-mata-ex-pareja-y.html|publisher=Público|date=2015-01-12|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Un hombre mata a su ex pareja y a la hermana en Elche y se suicida|url=http://www.elmundo.es/comunidad-valenciana/2015/01/12/54b3efda22601d4c488b4581.html|publisher=El Mundo|date=2015-01-12|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=La mujer asesinada en Elx, primera víctima mortal de violencia machista de 2015|url=http://www.levante-emv.com/sucesos/2015/01/12/mujer-asesinada-elx-primera-victima/1211291.html|publisher=Levante-EMV|date=2015-01-12|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * January 17: A woman (69) is killed in [[Orba, Alicante]]. Her partner flees to Germany, where he confesses the crime in the airport to police. Silent demonstrations were held in Alicante and Valencia.<ref>{{cite web|title=El presunto homicida de Alicante asfixió a la mujer 3 días antes de confesar|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/sucesos/20150120/54423560903/el-presunto-homicida-de-alicante-asfixio-a-la-mujer-3-dias-antes-de-confesar.html|publisher=La Vanguardia|date=2015-01-20|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * January 21: A man (44) kills his wife (39) and then he commits suicide in [[Terrassa]]. They had a 6 years old child. About 200 people meet in front of the city hall to protest against violence against women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mata a puñaladas a su mujer y luego se suicida en su piso de Terrassa|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/sucesos/20150121/54423831212/investigan-homicidio-de-una-mujer-y-suicidio-de-un-hombre-en-casa-de-terrassa.html|publisher=La Vanguardia|date=2015-01-21|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * February 4: A woman is stabbed to death by a man in [[Arrecife]]. They met some months ago.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mata a una mujer en Lanzarote y lo detienen cuando huía de la isla|url=http://www.eldiario.es/politica/Mata-mujer-Lanzarote-detienen-isla_0_353115748.html|publisher=El Diario|date=2015-02-04|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * February 6: A woman is strangled in [[Ronda]]. About 30 people protest against the crime.<ref>{{cite web|title=La autopsia revela que la turista alojada en Ronda murió estrangulada...|url=http://www.malagahoy.es/article/malaga/1956284/la/autopsia/revela/la/turista/alojada/ronda/murio/estrangulada.html|publisher=Málaga Hoy|date=2015-02-06|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * February 12: A man (47) stabs to death his partner (38) in [[Valencia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Detenido un hombre por matar a su pareja sentimental a cuchilladas|url=http://www.elmundo.es/comunidad-valenciana/2015/02/12/54dc7a6be2704ea6488b457e.html|publisher=El Mundo|date=2015-02-12|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * March 9: A man (75) confesses to have killed his wife (76) six months before in [[San Miguel de Salinas]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Hallan el cadáver de una mujer tras confesar su pareja que la mató a bastonazos|url=http://www.diarioinformacion.com/sucesos/2015/03/11/hallan-algorfa-cadaver-mujer-confesar/1608456.html|publisher=Diario Información|date=2015-03-11|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * March 10: A woman (43) in killed by her partner in [[Xàbia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Una mujer fallece tras ser golpeada con una sartén por su marido ante sus hijos en Xàbia|url=http://www.levante-emv.com/sucesos/2015/03/10/mujer-fallece-golpeada-sarten-marido/1236418.html|publisher=Levante-EMV|date=2015-03-10|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * March 12: A woman (23) is thrown out a van driven by her husband (24) in [[Cáceres, Spain|Cáceres]] and dies due to the injuries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fallece una joven cerca de Cáceres tras ser arrojada desde un vehículo|url=http://www.elperiodicoextremadura.com/noticias/caceres/fallece-joven-cerca-caceres-ser-arrojada-vehiculo_859568.html|publisher=El Periódico de Extremadura|date=2015-03-12|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sanidad confirma que la muerte de Tamara Simón fue un crimen de violencia de género|url=http://www.hoy.es/caceres/201503/17/sanidad-confirma-muerte-joven-20150317123410.html|publisher=Hoy|date=2015-03-17|accessdate=2015-10-06|language=Spanish}}</ref> * March 29: A man kills his wife (31) in [[Alhaurín de la Torre]] and then he commits suicide. About 100 people gather in the city hall square to protest against the crime.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hallan muerta a una pareja en un posible caso de violencia machista|url=http://www.diariosur.es/interior/201503/30/hallan-muerta-pareja-posible-20150330010847.html|publisher=Diario Sur|date=2015-03-30|accessdate=2015-10-09|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=La autopsia confirma que la muerte en Alhaurín es otro caso de violencia de género|url=http://www.laopiniondemalaga.es/municipios/2015/03/30/hallan-cadaveres-pareja-casa-alhaurin/754838.html|publisher=La Opinión de Málaga|date=2015-03-30|accessdate=2015-10-09|language=Spanish}}</ref> * March 30: A man shoots his wife (24) in [[Lleida]] and then attempts suicide.<ref>{{cite web|title=Un hombre mata a su mujer de un tiro en Lleida e intenta suicidarse|url=http://ccaa.elpais.com/ccaa/2015/03/30/catalunya/1427732666_717772.html|publisher=El País|date=2015-03-30|accessdate=2015-10-09|language=Spanish}}</ref> * April 2: A man (34) stabs his wife (29) to death in [[Vitoria-Gasteiz]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Una mujer muere acuchillada presuntamente por su pareja en Vitoria. Diario de Noticias de Alava|url=http://www.noticiasdealava.com/2015/04/02/araba/detenido-en-vitoria-por-acuchillar-hasta-la-muerte-a-su-pareja-en-el-domicilio-conyugal|publisher=Noticias de Álava|date=2015-04-02|accessdate=2015-10-09|language=Spanish}}</ref> * May 3: A man (50) kills his wife (47) and her boss (57) in [[Sorbas]] and [[Níjar]] respectively.<ref>{{cite web|title=Un hombre se entrega a la Guardia Civil tras matar a su mujer y al jefe de ésta en Almería|url=http://www.elmundo.es/andalucia/2015/05/03/55460fe6268e3eba1d8b4576.html|publisher=El Mundo|date=2015-05-03|accessdate=2015-10-09|language=Spanish}}</ref>
== 2016 == ===Gender violence murders=== 44 women were killed in [[gender violence]] cases.<ref>[http://www.violenciagenero.msssi.gob.es/violenciaEnCifras/victimasMortales/fichaMujeres/pdf/VMortales_2016_V2.pdf Official data] of Ministry of Health website</ref> *January 4: A man (41) strangles his partner (43) in [[Madrid]].<ref>[https://www.20minutos.es/noticia/2642473/0/mujer-asesinada/violencia-machista/estrangulada-pareja/ Muere una mujer de 43 años estrangulada por su pareja en Madrid] in 20minutos.es {{es}}</ref> *January 5: A man stabs his partner (33) in [[Galápagos, Guadalajara|Galápagos]], [[Province of Guadalajara|Guadalajara]].<ref>[https://politica.elpais.com/politica/2016/01/05/actualidad/1451981676_471998.html Una mujer es asesinada por su pareja a puñaladas en Guadalajara] in elpais.com {{es}}</ref> *January 7: A man (27) drowns his partner (21) in a [[swamp]] in [[Alange]], [[Province of Badajoz|Badajoz]].<ref>[http://www.hoy.es/prov-badajoz/martes-comienza-juicio-20180122195510-nt.html El juicio por el asesinato de una joven en Alange comienza este martes] in hoy.es {{es}}</ref> * January 11: A man is detained in [[Quintanar de la Orden]], [[Province of Toledo|Toledo]] after his wife (59) is found stabbed. He is released 4 days later becauses it is found that the DNA of the knife was his brother´s (the brother-in-law's victim),<ref>[http://www.elmundo.es/sociedad/2016/11/14/5829b069268e3e2d588b4594.html Detenido el hermano del "inocente" encarcelado por matar a su mujer en enero] in elmundo.es {{es}}</ref> who confessed the crime.<ref>[http://www.abc.es/espana/castilla-la-mancha/toledo/pueblos/abci-asesino-confeso-intento-suicidarse-despues-matar-cunada-201611152109_noticia.html El asesino confeso intentó suicidarse después de matar a su cuñada] in abc.es {{es}}</ref> Investigation still does not rule out an involvement of the husband.<ref>[http://www.abc.es/espana/castilla-la-mancha/toledo/pueblos/abci-crimen-quintanar-misterio-cuchillos-201801102041_noticia.html Crimen de Quintanar: el misterio de los dos cuchillos] in abc.es {{es}}</ref> *February 22: A man (41) shoots his ex-partner (37) in [[Zaragoza]].<ref>[https://www.heraldo.es/noticias/aragon/zaragoza-provincia/zaragoza/2016/02/22/nuevo-caso-violencia-genero-zaragoza-deja-dos-muertos-bar-miralbueno-777564-301.html Un hombre asesina a tiros a su expareja y luego se suicida en un bar de Miralbueno] in heraldo.es {{es}}</ref> *March 14: A man (46) is accused of stabbing his partner (34) in [[Gijón]], [[Province of The reason he was in prison is for killing with a hammer another girlfriend in 2002.<ref>[https://politica.elpais.com/politica/2018/06/21/actualidad/1529581456_113198.html Detenido por atacar a su novia con un martillo un condenado por matar a otra pareja a martillazos] in elpais.com {{es}}</ref> * August 13: A man (48) burns himself in Madrid after arguing with his partner (38) extending the fire around the building.<ref>[https://elpais.com/ccaa/2018/08/13/madrid/1534139635_595815.html?rel=mas Un hombre se prende fuego en Madrid tras discutir con su pareja e incendia el edificio] in elpais.com {{es}}</ref> * September 12: A woman (35) escapes from his partner (37) who has kidnapped her during four months in [[Fuenlabrada]], [[Province of Madrid|Madrid]].<ref>[https://elpais.com/sociedad/2018/09/11/actualidad/1536657156_345265.html Una mujer escapa de un secuestro y maltrato que ha durado cuatro meses] in elpais.com {{es}}</ref> * September 25: A man (48) stabs his 3 years old and 6 years old daughters in revenge of his wife (42) having denounced him. revision.text:
The '''Macy Conferences''' were a set of meetings of scholars from various disciplines held in New York under the direction of [[Frank Fremont-Smith]] at the [[Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation]] starting in 1941 and ending in 1960. The explicit aim of the conferences was to promote meaningful communication across scientific disciplines,<ref>von Foerster, H., Mead, M., & Teuber, H. L. (Eds.). (1951). ''Cybernetics: Circular causal and feedback mechanisms in biological and social systems. Transactions of the seventh conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. vii</ref> and restore unity to science.<ref>Fremont-Smith, F. (1960). The Macy Foundation conference plan. In M. Capes (Ed.), ''Communication or conflict: Conferences, their nature, dynamics and planning.'' New York: Association Press, pp. 218-19.</ref> There were different sets of conferences designed to cover specific topics, for a total of 160 conferences over the 19 years this program was active;<ref>Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation. (1960). ''A review of activities, 1956-1960.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. 7</ref> the phrase "Macy conference" does not apply only to those on cybernetics, although it is sometimes used that way informally by those familiar only with that set of events. Disciplinary isolation within medicine was viewed as particularly problematic by the Macy Foundation, and given that their mandate was to aid medical research, they decided to do something about it.<ref>von Foerster, H., Mead, M., & Teuber, H. L. (Eds.). (1952). ''Cybernetics: Circular causal and feedback mechanisms in biological and social systems. Transactions of the eighth conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. vii.</ref> Thus other topics covered in different sets of conferences included: aging, adrenal cortex, biological antioxidants, blood clotting, blood pressure, connective tissues, infancy and childhood, liver injury, metabolic interrelations, nerve impulse, problems of consciousness, and renal function.<ref>von Foerster, H., Mead, M., & Teuber, H. L. (Eds.). (1951). ''Cybernetics: Circular causal and feedback metchanisms in biological and social systems. Transactions of the seventh Conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. 7</ref>
== Overview == The Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation developed two innovations specifically designed to encourage and facilitate interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary exchanges; one was oral: the Macy conferences, and one was written: the Macy transactions (published transcriptions of the conferences). Macy conferences were essentially conversations held in a conference setting, with participants presenting research while it was still in process (rather than after it had been completed). These were more formal than conversations (papers were prepared ahead of time and circulated) but less formal than conferences. Macy transactions were transcriptions widely circulated to those who could not attend. These were far more informal than typical proceedings, which publish revised versions of conference papers, and served to invite additional scholars into the exchange.<ref name="Leeds-Hurwitz 1994 350-2">{{cite journal|last=Leeds-Hurwitz|first=Wendy|title=Crossing disciplinary boundaries: The Macy Foundation Conferences on Cybernetics as a case study in multidisciplinary communication|journal=Cybernetica: Journal of the International Association for Cybernetics|year=1994|volume=3/4|pages=350–352}}</ref> The explicit goal was to let a wider audience hear the experts exchange ideas and think out loud about their own work.<ref>Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation (1955). "The conference program". ''Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation 1930-1955: A review of activities.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation. p. 23.</ref> But even participants themselves found the transactions valuable, as a way to prompt memories, and to catch comments they might have missed.<ref>Schaffner, B. (Ed.). (1956). ''Group processes: Transactions of the second conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. 13.</ref> A few comments were made explicitly referring to later publication of the conference discussions, so clearly participants took this into account. However, Fremont-Smith explicitly stated that actual discussion should always take priority.<ref>von Foerster, H., Mead, M., & Teuber, H. L. (Eds.). (1950). ''Cybernetics: Circular causal and feedback mechanisms in biological and social systems. Transactions of the sixth conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, pp. 9-10.</ref>
Participants were leading scientists from a wide range of fields. Casual recollections of several participants as well as published comments in the Transactions volumes stress the communicative difficulties in the beginning of each set of conferences, giving way to the gradual establishment of a common language powerful enough to communicate the intricacies of the various fields of expertise present. Participants were deliberately chosen for their willingness to engage in interdisciplinary conversations, or for having formal training in multiple disciplines, and many brought relevant past experiences (gained either from earlier Macy conferences or other venues).<ref name="Leeds-Hurwitz 1994 p. 354">{{cite journal|last=Leeds-Hurwitz|first=Wendy|date=|title=Crossing disciplinary boundaries: The Macy Foundation Conferences on Cybernetics as a case study in multidisciplinary communication.|url=|journal=Cybernetica: Journal of the International Association for Cybernetics|issue=3/4|pages=349-369|via=}}</ref> As participants became more secure in their ability to understand one another over the course of a set of conferences on a single topic, their willingness to think outside their own specializations meant that creativity increased.<ref>von Foerster, H., Mead, M., & Teuber, H. L. (Eds.). (1954). ''Cybernetics: Circular causal and feedback mechanisms in biological and social systems. Transactions of the tenth Conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. 12.</ref>
== Conference topics ==
===Cerebral Inhibition Meeting=== The Macy Cybernetics Conferences were preceded by the '''Cerebral Inhibition Meeting,''' organized by [[Frank Fremont-Smith]] in May 1942.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asc-cybernetics.org/foundations/history2.htm|title=The Coalescence of Cybernetics|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=American Society for Cybernetics.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=4 December 2013}}</ref> This was an invitation only meeting attended by: {{Div col}}
* [[Gregory Bateson]] * [[Lawrence K. Frank]] * [[Margaret Mead]] * [[Warren McCulloch]] * [[Arturo Rosenblueth]] * Lawrence Kubie {{Div col end}} There were two topics: * [[Hypnotism]] introduced by [[Milton Erickson]] * [[Conditioned reflex]] introduced by [[Howard Liddell (psychologist)|Howard Liddell]]
===Cybernetics Conferences=== The Cybernetics conferences were held between 1946 and 1953, organized by the [[Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation]], motivated by [[Lawrence K. Frank]] and [[Frank Fremont-Smith]] of the Foundation.<ref name="ASC">[http://www.asc-cybernetics.org/foundations/history2.htm HISTORY OF CYBERNETICS] by the [[American Society for Cybernetics]], retrieved 15 April 2008</ref> As chair of this set of conferences, [[Warren McCulloch]] had responsibility to ensure that disciplinary boundaries were not unduly respected.<ref>von Foerster, H., Mead, M., & Teuber, H. L. (Eds.). (1952). ''Cybernetics: Circular causal and feedback mechanisms in biological and social systems. Transactions of the eighth conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. xix.</ref><ref>Bateson, G., & Mead, M. (1976). For God's sake, Margaret. ''Co-Evolution Quarterly,'' 32-44.</ref> The Cybernetics were particularly complex as a result of bringing together the most diverse group of participants of any of the Macy conferences, so they were the most difficult to organize and maintain.<ref name="Macy Foundation 1955">{{cite book|title=Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation 1930-1955: A review of activities|year=1955|publisher=Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation|location=New York|page=21|author=Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation|chapter=The conference program}}</ref>
The principal purpose of these series of conferences was to set the foundations for a ''general science of the workings of the human mind''.<ref name="summary">{{cite web|url=http://www.asc-cybernetics.org/foundations/history/MacySummary.htm |title=Summary: The Macy Conferences at asc-cybernetics.org. Accessed Dec 21, 2012 |publisher=Asc-cybernetics.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-28}}</ref> These were one of the first organized studies of [[interdisciplinarity]], spawning breakthroughs in [[systems theory]], [[cybernetics]], and what later became known as [[cognitive science]].{{fact|date=May 2018}}
One of the topics spanning a majority of the conferences was [[Self-reference|reflexivity]]. [[Claude Shannon]], one of the attendees, had previously worked on [[information theory]] and laid the one of the initial frameworks for the Cybernetic Conferences by postulating [[information]] as a probabilistic element which reduced the uncertainty from a set of choices (i.e. being told a statement is true, or even false, completely reduces the ambiguity of its message).
Other conference members, especially [[Donald MacCrimmon MacKay|Donald MacKay]], sought to reconcile Shannon’s view of [[information]], which they called selective information, with theirs of [[Structural information theory|'structural' information]] which signified how selective information was to be understood (i.e. a true statement might acquire additional meanings in varied settings though the information exchanged itself has not changed). The addition of meaning into the concept of information necessarily brought the role of the observer into the Macy Conferences. MacKay argued that by receiving and interpreting a message, the observer and the information they perceived ceased to exist independently of one another. The individual reading and processing the information does so relative to their preexisting internal state, consisting of what they already know and have experienced, and only then acts.
MacKay further muddled the role of information and its meaning by introducing the idea of [[Self-reference|reflexivity]] and feedback loops into his thought experiment. By claiming that the influence of the original message on the initial observer could be perceived by a separate individual, MacKay turned the second individual into an additional observer which could be elicited to react just how the initial observer did, a reaction that could then further be observed by a nested doll of observers ''ad infinitum''.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.7208/chicago/9780226321394.001.0001|title=How We Became Posthuman|last=Hayles|first=N. Katherine|date=1999|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=|isbn=9780226321462|location=|pages=55}}</ref>
[[Self-reference|Reflexive]] feedback loops continued to come up during the Macy Conferences and became a prominent issue during its later discussions as well, most notably in the discussions regarding [[Behavioral pattern|behavioral patterns]] of the [[human]] [[mind]].
[[Warren McCulloch]] and [[Walter Pitts]], also attendees, had previously worked on designing the first mathematical schema of a [[neuron]] based on the idea that each [[Artificial neuron|neuron]] had a threshold level that was to be reached, via excitation signals from incoming neurons, before firing its own [[signal]] onto others. Similarly to how Shannon had previously proven with his work in [[A Mathematical Theory of Communication|relay and switch circuits]], McCulloch and Pitts proved that [[Artificial neural network|neural networks]] were capable of carrying out any [[boolean algebra]] calculations.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.7208/chicago/9780226321394.001.0001|title=How We Became Posthuman|last=Hayles|first=N. Katherine|date=1999|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=|isbn=9780226321462|location=|pages=58}}</ref>
At the Macy Conferences, McCulloch proposed that the firing of a [[neuron]] can be associated with an event or interaction taking place in the external world which provides sensory stimulus that is then picked up by the [[nervous system]] and processed by the [[Neuron|neurons]].But McCulloch also showed how a [[Neural network|neural network's]] [[Transduction (physiology)|signal pathway]] could be set up [[Self-reference|reflexively]] with itself causing the neurons to continuously fire onto each other in a ‘reverberating’ circular [[feedback]] loop without any original ‘firing’ signal or any new additional incoming signals. McCulloch claimed this accounted for conscious phenomena in which individuals’ world view, or the reaffirmation of their senses’ perceived external stimulus, was [[Cognitive distortion|cognitively distorted]] or all together missing as seen in individuals with [[Phantom limb|phantom limb syndrome]] (claiming to feel an arm that has been amputated or lost) or [[hallucination]]<nowiki/>s (perceived sensory stimulus without an original external signal).<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.7208/chicago/9780226321394.001.0001|title=How We Became Posthuman|last=Hayles|first=N. Katherine|date=1999|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=|isbn=9780226321462|location=|pages=59}}</ref> Lawrence Kubie, another attending conference member and a psychiatrist, noted how repetitive and [[Obsessive–compulsive disorder|obsessive]] behaviors manifesting themselves in [[Neurosis|neurotics]] bore a resemblance to the behavior enacted by McCulloch’s ‘reverberating’ loops.
[[Claude Shannon|Shannon]] had developed a maze-solving device which attendees of the Macy Conferences likened to a rat. Shannon’s ‘rat’ was designed and programmed to find its marked goal when dropped at any point in a maze by giving it the ability to recall on past experiences, previous paths it had taken around the maze, so as to help it reach its endpoint - which it did repeatedly.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.7208/chicago/9780226321394.001.0001|title=How We Became Posthuman|last=Hayles|first=N. Katherine|date=1999|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=|isbn=9780226321462|location=|pages=64}}</ref>
Though goal-oriented, Shannon showed how his rat’s design was prone to erratic behavior that negated its original function entirely via [[Self-reference|reflexive]] [[feedback]] loops. If Shannon’s rat encountered itself in a path in which its ‘memory’ failed to fire correctly, that is to recall the paths which lead it to its goal, it would get stuck in an endless loop chasing its tail.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.7208/chicago/9780226321394.001.0001|title=How We Became Posthuman|last=Hayles|first=N. Katherine|date=1999|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=|isbn=9780226321462|location=|pages=65}}</ref> Completely abandoning its goal-oriented design, Shannon's rat had seemingly become neurotic.
The Macy Conferences failed to reconcile the subjectivity of information (its meaning) and that of the human mind but succeeding in showing how concepts such as that of the observer, [[Self-reference|reflexivity]], [[Black box|black box systems]], and [[Neural network|neural networks]] would have to be approached in conjunction and eventually overcome in order to form a complete working theory of the mind.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.7208/chicago/9780226321394.001.0001|title=How We Became Posthuman|last=Hayles|first=N. Katherine|date=1999|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=|isbn=9780226321462|location=|pages=69}}</ref> The Macy Conferences were discontinued shortly after the ninth conference.
:*First Cybernetics Conference, 21–22 March 1946 :*Second Cybernetics Conference, 17–18 October 1946 :*Third Cybernetics Conference, 13–14 March 1947 :*Fourth Cybernetics Conference, 23–24 October 1947 :*Fifth Cybernetics Conference, 18–19 March 1948 :*Sixth Cybernetics Conference, 24–25 March 1949 :*Seventh Cybernetics Conference, 23–24 March 1950 :*Eighth Cybernetics Conference, 15–16 March 1951 :*Ninth Cybernetics Conference, 20–21 March 1952 :*Tenth Cybernetics Conference, 22–24 April 1953

Amassian, [[William Ross Ashby]], [[Yehoshua Bar-Hillel]], [[Gregory Bateson]], Alex Bavelas, Julian H. Bigelow, Herbert G. Birch, John R. Bowman, Henry W. Brosin, [[Yuen Ren Chao]] (who memorably recited the ''[[Lion-Eating Poet in the Stone Den]]''), Jan Droogleever-Fortuyn, M. Ericsson, Fitch, [[Lawrence K. Frank]], [[Ralph Waldo Gerard]], [[William Grey Walter]], [[Molly Harrower]], [[George Evelyn Hutchinson]], [[Heinrich Klüver]], Lawrence S. Kubie, [[Paul Lazarsfeld]], [[Kurt Lewin]], [[J. C. R. Licklider]], [[Howard S. Liddell]], [[Donald B. Lindsley]], W. K. Livingston, [[David Lloyd (botanist)|David Lloyd]], [[Rafael Lorente de Nó]], [[R. Duncan Luce]], [[Donald M. MacKay]], [[Donald Marquis (psychologist)|Donald G. Marquis]], [[Warren S. McCulloch]], Turner McLardy, [[Margaret Mead]], Frederick A. Mettier, Marcel Monnier, [[Oskar Morgenstern]], [[F. S. C. Northrop]], [[Walter Pitts]], [[Henry Quastler]], Antoine Remond, [[I. A. Richards]], David McKenzie Rioch, [[Arturo Rosenblueth]], [[Leonard J. Savage]], [[T. C. Schneirla]], [[Claude Shannon]], John Stroud, [[Hans-Lukas Teuber]], Mottram Torre, Gerhardt von Bonin, [[Heinz von Foerster]], [[John von Neumann]], Heinz Werner, [[Norbert Wiener]], [[Jerome B. Wiesner]], [[J. Z. Young]].<ref>Leeds-Hurwitz, W. (1994). Crossing disciplinary boundaries: The Macy Foundation Conferences on Cybernetics as a case study in multidisciplinary communication. ''Cybernetica: Journal of the International Association for Cybernetics,'' 3/4, 363-364.</ref>
This is a sampling of the topics discussed each year.<ref name="summary" /> ;1946, March (NYC) :* Self-regulating and [[Teleology|teleological]] mechanisms :* Simulated [[neural network]]s emulating the calculus of propositional logic :* [[Anthropology]] and how [[computer]]s might learn how to learn :* Object perception's [[feedback]] mechanisms :* Perceptual differences due to [[brain damage]] :* Deriving [[ethics]] from science :* Compulsive repetitive behavior
;1946, October (NYC) :* [[Teleology | Teleological]] mechanisms in society :* Concepts from [[Gestalt psychology]] :* Tactile and chemical communications among ant soldiers
;1947, March (NYC) :* [[Child psychology]]
;1947, October (NYC) :* The field perspective on psychology :* Analog vs. digital approaches to [[psychological model]]s
;1948, Spring (NYC) :* Formation of "I" in language :* Formal modeling applied to chicken pecking order formation
;1949, March (NYC) :* Are the number of [[neuron]]s and their connections sufficient to account for human capacities? :* [[Memory]] :* An appeal for collaboration between physics and psychology
;1950, March (NYC) :* Analog vs. digital interpretations of the mind :* Language and [[Claude Shannon|Shannon]]'s [[information theory]] :* Language, symbols and [[neurosis]] :* [[Intelligibility (communication)|Intelligibility]] in speech communications :* A formal analysis of semantic redundancy in printed English
;1951, March (NYC) :* Information as semantic :* Can automatons engage in deductive logic? :* [[Decision theory]] :* Small group dynamics and group communications :* The applicability of game theory to psychic motivations :* The type of language needed to analyze language :* Mere behavior vs. true communication :* Is psychiatry scientific? :* Can a mental event that creates a memory ever be unconscious?
;1952, March (NYC) :* The relation of neurophysiological details to broad issues in philosophy and epistemology :* The relation of [[cybernetics]] at the microlevel to biochemical and cellular processes :* The [[complexity]] of organisms as a function of information :* Humor, communication, and paradox :* Do chess playing automatons need randomness to defeat humans? :* [[Homeostasis]] and learning
;1953, April (Princeton) :* Studies on the activity of the brain<ref name=":0">{{Cite book | title = Cybernetics {{!}} The Macy-Conferences 1946-1953 | last = Pias | first = Claus | publisher = Diaphanes | year = 2003 | isbn = 3037345985 | location = Zurich-Berlin | pages = }}</ref> :* Semantic information and its measures<ref name=":0" /> :* Meaning in language and how its acquired<ref name=":0" /> :* How neural mechanisms can recognize shapes and musical chords :* What consensus, if any, the Macy Conferences have arrived at
Some of the researchers present at the cybernetics conferences later went on to do extensive government-funded research on the psychological effects of LSD, and its potential as a tool for [[interrogation]] and [[psychological manipulation]] in such projects as the [[CIA]]'s [[MKULTRA]] program.<ref>Unsworth, John M., [http://people.lis.illinois.edu/~unsworth/SLS.htm "LSD, Mind Control, and the Internet: A Chronology"], handout with "Information Theory, Postmodernism, and Mind Control (or, What LSD, Mass Media, and the Internet Have in Common)," presented at the 1994 Conference of the Society for Literature and Science, New Orleans, LA, November, 1994.</ref>
===Neuropharmacological Conferences=== ;First Neuropharmacological Conference, 26–28 May 1954 Participants: [[William Borberg]], Seymour Kety, Ernest Sharrer, Mary Brazier, Horace Magoun, Carl Pfieffer Topics: [[LSD]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Glaser|first=Gilbert|journal=The Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine|date=September 1955|volume=28|issue=1|pages=78–79|url=http://www.deepdyve.com/lp/pubmed-central/neuropharmacology-transactions-of-the-first-conference-r6230S6B0v/1|title=Neuropharmacology - Transactions of the first conference |accessdate=4 March 2013}}</ref>
===Group Processes Conferences=== The Group Processes Conferences were held between 1954 and 1958. They are of particular interest due to the element of reflexivity: participants were interested in their own functioning as a group, and made numerous comments about their understanding of how Macy conferences were designed to work.<ref name="Leeds-Hurwitz 1994">{{cite journal|last=Leeds-Hurwitz|first=Wendy|title=Crossing disciplinary boundaries: The Macy Foundation Conferences on Cybernetics as a case study in multidisciplinary communication|journal=Cybernetica: Journal of the International Association for Cybernetics|year=1994|volume=3/4|page=350}}</ref> For example, there were a series of jokes made about the disease afflicting them all, interdisciplinitis.,<ref>Schaffner, B. (Ed.). (1957). ''Group processes: Transactions of the third conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. 10</ref> or how multidisciplinarian researchers were neither fish nor fowl.<ref>Schaffner, B. (Ed.). (1955). ''Group processes: Transactions of the first conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. 307.</ref> When [[Erving Goffman]] made a guest appearance at the Third conference, he explicitly prefaced his comments by saying that his ideas were partly speculative, and [[Frank Fremont-Smith]] responded by stating that their goal was to discuss ideas that had not been crystallized.<ref>Schaffner, B. (Ed.). (1957). ''Group processes: Transactions of the third conference.'' New York: Josiah Macy, Jr. Foundation, p. 144.</ref>
:*First Group Processes Conference, 26–30 September 1954 :*Second Group Processes Conference, 9–12 October 1955 :*Third Group Processes Conference, 7–10 October 1956 :*Fourth Group Processes Conference, 13–16 October 1957 :*Fifth Group Processes Conference, 12–15 October 1960
