{{Infobox organization | image = Shelter Cluster.jpg | alt = | caption = Logo of the Shelter Cluster | formation = {{Start date|2006}} | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | type = Coordination mechanism | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = Coordinate humanitarian shelter | headquarters = | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | language = <!-- official languages --> | leader_title = Global Shelter Cluster Coordinator | leader_name = Brett Moore, [[UNHCR]] | leader_title2 = Global Shelter Cluster Coordinator | leader_name2 = Ela Serdaroglu, [[IFRC]] | key_people = | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | affiliations = [[Inter-Agency Standing Committee]] | budget = | remarks = | name = Shelter Cluster | former name = Emergency Shelter Cluster | size = frameless | location = | region_served = | membership = | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{url| www.sheltercluster.org}} }} The '''Shelter Cluster''' is an [[Inter-Agency Standing Committee]] (IASC) coordination mechanism that supports people affected by [[natural disaster]]s and [[armed conflict|conflicts]] with the means to live in safe, dignified and appropriate [[Shelter (building)|shelter]]. The Shelter Cluster is one of eleven sectorial coordination groups<ref>{{cite web |url= https://clusters.humanitarianresponse.info/about-clusters/what-is-the-cluster-approach |title= What is the Cluster Approach|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | title = Global Cluster Leads | url = http://reliefweb.int/map/world/global-cluster-leads-june-2012 | date = 25 June 2012 | publisher = [[UNOCHA]] }}</ref> that are part of the [[Internally Displaced Person#The Cluster Approach|Cluster Approach]], that followed the Humanitarian Response Review in 2005.<ref>{{Citation | publisher = Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) | title = Guidance Note on Using the Cluster Approach to Strengthen Humanitarian Response | pages = 3 | date = 24 November 2006 | url = http://www.refworld.org/docid/460a8ccc2.html }}</ref><ref name=ECHO>{{Cite report | author = Michel Vanbruaene |author2=Tom Corsellis |author3=Bernard Crenn |author4=Jonathan Price |author5=Paul Mbatha |author6=Dieter Tranchant |author7=Maria Lourdes Domingo-Price | date = 9 August 2013 | title = Evaluation of the European Commission’s Humanitarian Action in the Shelter Sector – Final Report | url = http://ec.europa.eu/echo/files/evaluation/2013/shelter_ExecSummary.pdf | publisher = European Commission Humanitarian and Civil Protection (ECHO) | section = Executive Summary | page = iii | accessdate = 22 October 2013 }}</ref> Currently 43 humanitarian organizations are part of the Shelter Cluster at global level,<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sheltercluster.org/about-us |title= About Us |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |accessdate=25 September 2013}}</ref> more than 500 organizations coordinate shelter assistance with the support of the Shelter Cluster at country level. <ref>{{Citation | title = GSC Achievements Report 2016 | url = http://www.sheltercluster.org/global/documents/gsc-achievements-report-2016 }}</ref>
The Shelter Cluster’s scope includes all activities related to achieving the right to adequate housing with a humanitarian focus. This includes:<ref>{{Citation | title = Scope of the Global Shelter Cluster | url = https://www.sheltercluster.org/about-us/documents/gsc-scope-121017final }}</ref>
* emergency and longer term shelter support * shelter-related non-food-items (NFIs) * housing construction and reconstruction * settlement support such as site planning and urban planning * shelter preparedness and risk reduction.
== Structure ==
The Global Shelter Cluster is co-chaired by the [[UNHCR|United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)]]<ref>{{Citation | title = UNHCR Global Report 2006 | publisher = [[UNHCR]] | url = http://www.unhcr.org/4a2fd85b6.pdf | date = 30 June 2007 | location = Geneva | pages = 40–43 }}</ref> and the [[IFRC|International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC)]].<ref name=ECHO/>{{rp|iv}}<ref>{{Citation | last = Davidson | first = Sara | last2 = Price | first2 = Gill | title = Review of the International Federation's Shelter Cluster Commitment | publisher = [[IFRC]] | url = http://www.ifrc.org/docs/evaluations/Evaluations2010/Geneva/Review%20of%20IFRC%20Shelter%20Cluster%20Final%2009%2001%2010.pdf | date = 9 January 2010 | location = Geneva | pages = 10 }}</ref> The IFRC convenes the Shelter Cluster in natural disaster situations.<ref>{{Citation | title = FAQ: The cluster process and the International Federation’s Shelter Cluster commitment | url = http://www.pacificdisaster.net/pdnadmin/data/original/IFRC_SHELTER_2009_cluster_FAQ.pdf | year = 2009 | publisher = [[IFRC]] }}</ref> UNHCR leads the Shelter Cluster in conflict situations where there are [[Internally displaced person]]s, whereas in [[refugee]] situations the core mandate of UNHCR takes precedence over the cluster system.<ref name=ECHO/>{{rp|iv}}<ref>{{Citation | publisher = Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) | title = 4. Reference Module for Cluster Coordination at the Country Level | pages = 3 | date = November 2012 | url = http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Reference%20Module%20for%20Cluster%20Coordination%20at%20the%20Country%20Level.pdf | accessdate = 22 October 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | title = Cluster Approach Evaluation 2 Synthesis Report | last1 = Streets | first1 = Julia | last2 = Grünewald | first2 = François | last3 = Binder | first3 = Andrea | last4 = Geoffroy, de | first4 = Véronique | last5 = Kauffmann | first5 = Domitille | last6 = Krüger | first6 = Susanna | last7 = Meier | first7 = Claudia | last8 = Sokpoh | first8 = Bonaventure | url = http://www.gppi.net/fileadmin/gppi/GPPi-URD_Cluster_II_Evaluation_SYNTHESIS_REPORT_e.pdf | date = April 2010 | publisher = Global Public Policy Institute | pages = 25 }}</ref> The IFRC is convening the Cluster and not leading it because, as a neutral and impartial organization, it cannot be part of the command structure of the United Nations. This difference was formalized in Memorandum of Understanding between the IFRC and [[UNOCHA|The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs]].<ref>{{Citation | title = Memorandum of Understanding between International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies and United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs in regards to the International Federation Assuming a Leading Role in Emergency Shelter in Natural Disasters | url = http://www.sheltercluster.org/about-us/documents/mou-between-ocha-ifrc-regards-international-federation-assuming-leading-role | date = 19 September 2006 | location = Geneva/New York }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | last = Stoddard | first = Abby | last2 = Harmer | first2 = Adele | last3 = Salomons | first3 = Dirk | last4 = Wheeler | first4 = Victoria | publisher = Humanitarian Policy Group | title = Cluster Approach Evaluation - Final | pages = 35 | date = 1 November 2007 | url = http://www.odi.org.uk/sites/odi.org.uk/files/odi-assets/publications-opinion-files/4955.pdf | accessdate = 22 October 2013 | ISBN = 9780850038637 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation | title = Inter-Agency Standing Committee Principals Meeting - Conclusions and Action Points | url = http://www.humanitarianinfo.org/iasc/downloaddoc.aspx?docID=3648 | date = 12 December 2006 | accessdate= 26 September 2013 }}</ref>
The structure of the Global Shelter Cluster includes:<ref name=management>{{Citation | title = Management Structure of the Global Shelter Cluster | url = https://www.sheltercluster.org/about-us/documents/gsc-structure-120925 }}</ref>
* Global Shelter Cluster Meeting: the highest governing body of the Global Shelter Cluster. It meets twice a year to review progress against agreed objectives and define the Global Shelter Cluster strategic direction and annual priorities. It appoints members of the Strategic Advisory Group (SAG). * Strategic Advisory Group (SAG): a permanent body that works to advance the Cluster’s strategic direction and overall work plan. The SAG is elected by and composed of agencies and institutions that are part of the Global Shelter Cluster.
The Shelter Cluster’s structure also include working groups, communities of practice and other support mechanisms.<ref name=management />
== Operations ==
Since its inception in 2006, the Shelter Cluster has coordinated humanitarian shelter assistance in 43 responses.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.sheltercluster.org/ |title= Shelter Cluster|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Francisco Xavier Garmendia
[[Víctor Rabú]]{{cite web |url=http://historico.elpais.com.uy/03/04/13/pciuda_37045.asp |title=Historicist fervor |date=13 April 2003 |publisher=[[El País (Uruguay)|EL PAIS]]|language=es}} |owner = Government of Montevideo |capacity = 1500 |type = Municipal ([[Montevideo]]) |opened = 1856 |yearsactive =161 |restored = 1996 - 2004 |closed = |othernames = |production = |currentuse = Opera, Ballet, Concerts, Plays |website = www.teatrosolis.org.uy |native_name=}} '''Solís Theatre''' (''Spanish'': '''Teatro Solís''') is [[Uruguay]]'s most important and renowned theatre. It opened in 1856 and the building was designed by the Italian architect [[Carlo Zucchi]]. It is located in Montevideo's Old Town, right next to the [[Plaza Independencia]]. In 1998, the government of Montevideo started a major reconstruction of the theatre, which included two columns designed by [[Philippe Starck]]. The reconstruction was completed in 2004 with the re-opening taking place in August of that year.[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/archivo/Nota.asp?nota_id=630831 "Se reabrió el Teatro Solís", ''La Nacion'', 27 August 2004] Acoustic studies of the rehabilitation project was entrusted to Jerome Falala of the French studio ''Avel Acoustique''. [[Tomás Giribaldi]]'s ''La Parisina'', considered the first Uruguayan national opera, was premiered at the Solís on September 14, 1878. == See also == *[[Montevideo]] *[[Ciudad Vieja, Montevideo]] *[[Plaza Independencia]] *[[List of music venues#Uruguay|List of music venues in Uruguay]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{commons category|Teatro Solís (Montevideo)}} *[http://www.teatrosolis.org.uy/ Official theatre website] Retrieved 4 December 2013 *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121115211500/http://viajes.elpais.com.uy/2011/05/16/teatro-solis-que-lo-merezcamos/ Details (including photos) of the theatre] on viajes.elpais.com.uy Retrieved 4 December 2012 {{Ciudad Vieja, Montevideo}} {{coord|34|54|29|S|56|12|04|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Solis Theatre}} [[Category:Neoclassical architecture in Uruguay]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Montevideo]] [[Category:Theatres in Uruguay]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1856]] [[Category:Ciudad Vieja, Montevideo]] [[Category:1856 establishments in Uruguay]] {{Uruguay-struct-stub}} {{Theat-struct-stub}}

[[Laura Pendergest-Holt]], [[chief investment officer]]
[[James M. Davis|James Davis]], [[chief financial officer|CFO]] | industry = Global financial services | products = | services = Wealth management | market cap = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = [[Allen Stanford|Robert Allen Stanford]] | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = Stanford Capital Management
Stanford Group Company
[[Stanford International Bank]] Ltd | subsid = | homepage = {{URL |http://www.stanfordfinancialgroup.com/}} (offline) | footnotes = | intl = }} The '''Stanford Financial Group''' was a privately held international group of [[financial services]] companies controlled by [[Allen Stanford]], until it was seized by [[United States]] (U.S.) authorities in early 2009. Headquartered in the [[Galleria Office Towers|Galleria Tower II]] in [[Uptown Houston]], [[Texas]], it had 50 offices in several countries, mainly in the Americas, included the [[Stanford International Bank]], and said it managed US$8.5 billion of assets for more than 30,000 clients in 136 countries on six continents."[http://www.stanfordfinancial.com/contact_us_north_america Contact Us > North America]." ''Stanford Financial Group''. Retrieved on February 18, 2009. On February 17, 2009, U.S. Federal agents placed the company into [[receivership]] due to charges of fraud.See generally, ''Securities and Exchange Commission, Plaintiff v. Stanford International Bank Ltd., Stanford Group Company, Stanford Capital Management LLC, R. Allen Stanford, James M. Davis, Laura Pendergest-Holt, Defendants'', case no. 3:09-cv-00298-L; U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas (Dallas). Ten days later, the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] amended its complaint to accuse Stanford of turning the company into a "massive [[Ponzi scheme]]".{{Cite news |first=Anna |last=Driver |title=U.S. charges Stanford with massive Ponzi scheme |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSTRE51Q66G20090228 |work=[[Reuters]] |publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]] |date=27 February 2009 |accessdate=28 February 2009 }} == History == Allen Stanford traced his company to the insurance company founded in 1932 in [[Mexia, Texas]], by his grandfather, Lodis B. Stanford.{{cite web|url=http://www.stanfordfinancial.com/business_overview|title=Company history|publisher=stanfordfinancial.com|accessdate=2009-02-17}} However, there was no direct connection between the insurance company and Allen Stanford's banking business, which he started on the [[British Overseas Territory]] of [[Montserrat]] in the [[West Indies]] in the 1980s.{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article5755684.ece|title=Profile: Behind Allen Stanford's easy charm there is the glint of steel|last=Kidd |first=Patrick |date=February 18, 2009|publisher=timesonline.co.uk|accessdate=2009-02-17 | location=London}} Allen Stanford's move into banking utilised funds he had made in real estate in Houston in the early 1980s. In 2008, Stanford Financial Group announced it would open a new global management complex in [[St. Croix, U.S. Virgin Islands]], to include the base for the corporate support functions such as business technology, compliance, finance, human resources, investment strategy and legal, as well as the chairman's office. Completion was planned for July 2009 but did not occur due to the company's dissolution.{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/stanford-financial-group-to-expand-in-the-caribbean-56851517.html|title=Stanford Financial Group To Expand in the Caribbean|last=Group|first=Stanford Financial|website=www.prnewswire.com|access-date=2017-01-10}} [[File:GalleriaTowerIIHoustonTX.JPG|thumb|[[Galleria Tower II]], the headquarters of Stanford Financial Group in Houston]] [[File:StanfordOffice2.JPG|thumb|Offices for Stanford Financial Group in [[Houston]] – This building formerly had the headquarters]] [[File:FortBend 420.JPG|thumb|Stanford Aviation Terminal at [[Sugar Land Regional Airport]]]] The company was bound by a web of personal and family ties. Stanford's [[chief financial officer]] and second-in-command, [[James M. Davis]], was his roommate at [[Baylor University]]. The [[chief investment officer]], [[Laura Pendergest-Holt]], grew up attending a church in [[Baldwyn, Mississippi]] where Davis was a [[Sunday school]] teacher. Many top officials were related to each other. This led former employees to claim the company was fraught with nepotism; former executive Charles Satterfield told [[Bloomberg News]] that whenever someone asked questions, a common response was "I'm not going to question my brother-in-law."Forsythe, Michael and Alison Fitzgerald.[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aw1dZUb28Qc8&refer=home Stanford Prayer With Dying Man Pumped Agents in Alleged Fraud], Bloomberg, March 9, 2009. ==Affiliated companies== Stanford Financial Group comprised several affiliated companies: *Stanford Financial Group Company (SFGC) was an entity based in Houston, Texas, USA, that provided financial services to several of the affiliated companies, and in particular to Stanford International Bank Limited (SIBL). The services were provided via a "Services Agreement" that paved the way for investor deposits to be funneled via a circuitous route to multiple destinations, including affiliated companies that leased multiple corporate jets, owned yachts, funded a cricket pitch and even a Swiss bank account used to bribe officials.{{cite news|url=https://www.pacermonitor.com/public/case/4217866/Janvey_v_Maldonado|title= Janvey v. Maldonado Case 3:14-cv-02826 doc 103|accessdate=2015-10-09}} * Stanford Capital Management, investment adviser, based on Houston{{cite news|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29237750/ |title=Stanford Financial charged with 'massive' fraud|publisher=msnbc.msn.com|accessdate=2009-02-17}} * Stanford Group Company, broker-dealer, based in Houston * [[Stanford International Bank]], was started in 1986 in [[Montserrat]] where it was called Guardian International Bank. Allen Stanford relocated its operations to Antigua.{{cite news |url=http://www.businessweek.com/investing/wall_street_news_blog/archives/2009/02/stanfords_faile.html |title=Stanford's Failed Health Club |last=Goldstein|first=Matthew |publisher=businessweek.com|accessdate=2009-02-17}} On February 19, 2009 Nigel Hamilton-Smith and Peter Wastell of the British accounting firm [[Vantis]] were appointed joint [[receivership|receivers]] of the bank,[http://www.fsrc.gov.ag/ Financial Services Regulatory Commission], Antigua and Barbuda. News Archive. Retrieved 2010-06-09. and were made [[Liquidator (law)|liquidators]] on April 15, 2009.[http://www.businesswire.com/portal/site/google/?ndmViewId=news_view&newsId=20090416005409&newsLang=en) Stanford International Bank Limited Placed into Liquidation], BusinessWire, 16 April 2009. Retrieved 2010-06-09. In June 2010, the High Court of Antigua resolved that Vantis should be removed from its responsibilities. The firm, which had recently received government approval to sell the property assets, appealed the decision.[http://www.accountancyage.com/accountancyage/news/2264604/antigua-court-wants-remove Antigua court wants to remove Vantis from Stanford liquidation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820094205/http://www.accountancyage.com/accountancyage/news/2264604/antigua-court-wants-remove |date=2010-08-20 }}, ''Accountancy Age'', 11 June 2010. Retrieved 2010-06-11. * Stanford Trust Company, helped manage and protect wealth.{{cite web|url=http://www.stanfordtrustco.com/about/about_stc.aspx|title=ABOUT STANFORD TRUST COMPANY|publisher=stanfordtrustco.com|accessdate=2009-02-17|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109220718/http://www.stanfordtrustco.com/about/about_stc.aspx|archive-date=2009-01-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=aUtjE4_bm4oM&refer=news |title=Billionaire Stanford’s Firm Said to Face U.S. Probe (Update1) |last=Fitzgerald|first=Alison|date=February 12, 2009 |publisher=bloomberg.com |accessdate=2009-02-17}} Vantis was also appointed receivers of Stanford Trust Company."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7902667.stm Stanford bank in Antigua seized]." [[BBC]]. February 21, 2009. Retrieved on July 27, 2009. *[[Bank of Antigua]] * Stanford Coins and Bullion ==Sponsorships and charity == In 2007, Stanford Financial Group assumed title sponsorship of the [[Stanford St. Jude Championship]], a top [[PGA Tour]] event to benefit [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (Memphis, Tennessee)|St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]] of [[Memphis, Tennessee]]. On March 20, 2009, after the Group's fraud was revealed, the PGA announced that they would be dropping their affiliation with the company and that for 2009 the event would be called the St. Jude's Classic.[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090319/ap_on_sp_go_ne/glf_pga_memphis;_ylt=Au69rxIghRrh4OyHmC3DGh0LMxIF Stanford Name Removed from PGA Stop] Yahoo Sports, March 20, 2009 Stanford Financial Group was the lead financier for the 2007 film ''[[The Ultimate Gift]]'',.{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=ultimategift.htm | title=The Ultimate Gift | publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=2007-05-25 }} According to the Association for Healthcare Philanthropy, the story of ''The Ultimate Gift'' promoted [[philanthropy]] in not-for-profit [[health care]] institutions.{{cite web|url=http://www.ahp.org/other/tugx.php |title=AHP and The Ultimate Gift Experience |publisher=ahp.org |accessdate=2009-02-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061004073931/http://www.ahp.org/other/tugx.php |archivedate=October 4, 2006 }} The group established a significant presence in [[golf]], [[polo]], [[tennis]], [[cricket]] and [[sailing]], sports which were popular among Stanford’s wealthy clients. Stanford Financial Group was the title sponsor for such sporting events as the Stanford U.S. Open Polo Championship, the Stanford USPA Silver Cup, the Stanford Antigua Sailing Week, the PGA Tour Stanford St. Jude Championship, and the Stanford International Pro-Am. Stanford also sponsored professional golfers [[Vijay Singh]], [[Camilo Villegas]] and [[David Toms]] as well as [[Morgan Pressel]] on the LPGA Tour. In tennis, the company was a sponsor of the [[Sony Ericsson Open]]. Stanford also sponsored the [[Outback Champions Series|Champions Series]] Tennis Tournaments featuring [[Jim Courier]], [[John McEnroe]] and [[Pete Sampras]]. The [[Stanford Financial Tour Championship]], previously known as the [[LPGA]] Playoffs at The ADT and the [[ADT Security Services|ADT]] Championship, was the season-ending [[golf]] tournament on the US-based [[LPGA Tour]]. Beginning with the 2009 event, it was to be sponsored by Stanford Financial Group.{{cite news|url=http://www.lpga.com/content_1.aspx?pid=18166&mid=1|title=Stanford Financial Group further expands profile in Golf as new title sponsor of LPGA Tour Championship|publisher=lpga.com|accessdate=2009-02-17}} As one of the founding partners, Stanford Financial Group was also involved in [[Tiger Woods]]'s annual golf tournament, the [[AT&T National]].{{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/golf/entries/2009/02/17/feds_to_stanford_youre_ob.html|title=Feds to Stanford: You’re OB|last=Robbins|first=Kevin |date=February 17, 2009|publisher=Austin American-Statesman|accessdate=2009-02-17}} ==Regulatory investigation== During the week of February 13, 2009, Stanford issued a letter to clients saying: "Regulatory officers have visited our offices and have stated that these are routine examinations".{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/business/6263269.html|title=Billionaire downplays scrutiny of Stanford Financial|last=Hays|first=Kristen |author2=Mary Flood |date=February 13, 2009|publisher=Houston Chronicle|accessdate=2009-02-17}} On February 17, 2009, U.S. Federal agents entered the company's Houston and Memphis offices.{{cite news|url=http://www.myfoxmemphis.com/dpp/news/021709_Feds_Raid_Stanford_Financial_Group_Offices|title=Feds Raid Stanford Financial Group Offices|date=February 17, 2009|publisher=WHBQ|accessdate=2009-02-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090223103341/http://www.myfoxmemphis.com/dpp/news/021709_Feds_Raid_Stanford_Financial_Group_Offices|archivedate=February 23, 2009|df=}} Law enforcement officials placed signs on the office doors stating that the company was temporarily closed: "The company is still in operation but under the management of a [[receiver (legal)|receiver]]".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/18/business/18stanford.html?ref=business|title=U.S. Accuses Texas Financial Firm of $8 Billion Fraud|last=Krauss|first=Clifford |author2=Phillip L. Zweig |author3=Julie Creswell|accessdate=2009-02-17 | work=The New York Times | date=February 18, 2009}} {{Quote box | quote =''"The company is still in operation but under the management of a receiver."'' —Signs placed February 17, 2009 at Houston office by law enforcement | source = | width =25% | align =right }}The [[Securities Exchange Commission]]'s (SEC) charged Allen Stanford, Pendergest-Holt and Davis of fraud{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSN1736672620090217?feedType=RSS&feedName=domesticNews&rpc=22&sp=true |title=U.S. agents enter Stanford Financial Houston office|last=Driver|first=Anna |date=February 17, 2009|publisher=reuters.com|accessdate=2009-02-17}}{{cite news |title=Billionaire Stanford Charged With Fraud|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/02/17/allen-stanford-sec-business-billionaires_0217_stanford.html |last=Greenberg |first=Duncan |date=February 17, 2009|publisher=forbes.com|accessdate=2009-02-17}} in connection with Stanford Financial Group's US$8 billion [[certificate of deposit]] (CD) investment scheme that offered "improbable and unsubstantiated high interest rates".{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/story/2009/02/17/ST2009021701544.html |title=SEC Charges Stanford Financial in $8B Fraud|last=Goldfarb|first=Zachary A. |date=February 17, 2009|publisher=washingtonpost.com |accessdate=2009-02-17}} This led the Federal government to freeze the assets of Allen Stanford, Stanford International Bank, Stanford Group Co., and Stanford Capital Management. In addition, Stanford International Bank placed a 60-day moratorium on early redemptions of its CDs.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aeHvNZJLOWf0&refer=home |title=Stanford International Bank Said to Bar Withdrawals Amid Probe |last=Fitzgerald |first=Alison |date=February 17, 2009|publisher=bloomberg.com |accessdate=2009-02-17}} On February 18 and 19, 2009, [[Ecuador]] and [[Peru]] suspended the operations of local Stanford units, and, in [[Venezuela]] and [[Panama]], the governments seized local units of Stanford Bank.{{cite news | title = Stanford probe widens, Venezuela seizes bank | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/americasMergersNews/idUKN1950667820090219?sp=true | authors = Ana Isabel Martinez and Jason Szep | publisher = Reuters | date = February 19, 2009 }} [[Mexico]]'s financial regulator announced on February 19 that it was investigating the local affiliate of Stanford bank for possible violation of banking laws. On February 27, 2009, Stanford official Laura Pendergest-Holt was arrested by Federal agents in connection with the alleged fraud.{{cite news | title = Top Stanford official Laura Pendergest-Holt charged with obstruction | date = February 27, 2009 | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article5812952.ece | work=The Times | location=London | first=Suzy | last=Jagger | accessdate=May 24, 2010}} On that day the SEC said that Stanford and his accomplices operated a "massive Ponzi scheme", misappropriated billions of dollars of investors' money and falsified the Stanford International Bank's records to hide their fraud. "Stanford International Bank's financial statements, including its investment income, are fictional," the SEC said.[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB123577641445497313?mod=googlenews_wsj New SEC Complaint Says Stanford Ran Ponzi Scheme], [[Wall Street Journal]], February 27, 2009 United States District Judge David Godbey froze all of the Stanford personal and corporate assets. Godbey gave them to Ralph Janvey, a [[Dallas]] receiver; Janvey will retain control until the SEC suit is resolved."[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/business/stanford/6459688.html Stanford criticizes receiver fees as ‘unbridled’]." ''[[Bloomberg News]]'' at ''[[Houston Chronicle]]''. June 5, 2009. Retrieved on June 22, 2009. A British receiver took the Antigua-based Stanford International Bank.Sweeney, John. "[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8029494.stm Stanford drug informer role claim]." ''[[BBC]]''. Saturday May 9, 2009. Retrieved on June 22, 2009. On July 1, 2009, [[James M. Davis]], the CFO of the company, agreed to change course from his not guilty plea and plead guilty to three charges related to the Ponzi scheme fraud, once details can be worked out. On November 13, 2009 The US District Court Ordered Brokerage Accounts to be transferred to [[Dominick & Dominick LLC]]. The transfer became effective on January 20, 2010.Stanford Financial Group Receivership http://stanfordfinancialreceivership.com/ In 2011, an auction of Stanford's goods was held in Houston."[http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/tx/7591897.html Ex-financier Stanford's effects face Texas auction]." ''[[Associated Press]]'' at the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]''. June 2, 2011. Retrieved on June 3, 2011. On March 19, 2012 the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned a federal judge’s ruling from the previous year that threw out three class action lawsuits that are trying to use state laws to recover investor losses resulting from Stanford’s scheme. The ruling allows lawsuits by investors who lost millions in Stanford Ponzi scheme to go forward against several 3rd parties.{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/court-allows-lawsuits-by-investors-who-lost-millions-in-stanford-ponzi-scheme-to-go-forward/2012/03/19/gIQA6YMbNS_story.html }} {{Dead link|date=June 2012|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} ==Headquarters== Stanford was headquartered in the [[Galleria Office Towers|Galleria Tower II]] in [[Uptown Houston]], [[Texas]], U.S."[http://www.galleriatowers.com/building.aspx?b=10 Tower 2] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090601205217/http://galleriatowers.com/building.aspx?b=10 |date=2009-06-01 }}." ''[[Galleria Office Towers]]''. Retrieved on February 22, 2009."[http://www.uptown-houston.com/about/organization/district-map.html Uptown District Map]." ''Uptown Houston District''. Retrieved on January 30, 2009. Previously the company was headquartered in 5050 [[Westheimer Road]],"[https://archive.is/20060127100941/http://www.stanfordfinancial.com/displayContent.asp?categoryID=150 Contact]." Stanford Financial Group. January 27, 2006. Retrieved on June 22, 2009. a three-story, {{convert|71000|sqft|sqm}} building across from [[The Galleria (Houston)|The Galleria]]. Jennifer Dawson of the ''[[Houston Business Journal]]'' described the facility as "high-end office digs."Dawson, Jennifer. "[http://houston.bizjournals.com/houston/stories/2010/07/05/story1.html?q=Stanford%205050%20Westheimer Scheduled Stanford auction scratched as no bids show for building]." ''[[Houston Business Journal]]''. Friday July 2, 2010. Retrieved on August 25, 2010. By 2007 Stanford's headquarters moved to Galleria Tower II."[https://archive.is/20070124114500/http://www.stanfordfinancial.com/displayContent.asp?categoryID=150 Contact]." Stanford Financial Group. January 24, 2007. Retrieved on June 22, 2009. On May 18, 2010 the receiver entered into a [[Stalking horse offer|stalking horse contract]] for the sale of 5050 Westheimer Road."[http://www.stanfordfinancialreceivership.com/#5050Westheimer Notice of Public Auction for Sale of 5050 Westheimer, Houston, Texas]." Stanford Financial Receivership. Retrieved on August 25, 2010."[http://www.stanfordfinancialreceivership.com/documents/5050_Notice.pdf NOTICE OF PUBLIC AUCTION OF REAL PROPERTY IN HARRIS COUNTY, TEXAS]." Stanford Financial Receivership. Retrieved on August 25, 2010. During that month Black Forest Ventures LLC was the designated bidder to defeat at the auction, with a minimum bid being $12.5 million. The auction was scheduled to be held on Thursday June 24, 2010 at the offices of [[Baker Botts, L.L.P.]] in [[One Shell Plaza]] in [[Downtown Houston]]. The auction was canceled due to a lack of bids, and Black Forest's stipulated that it would acquire the building for $12.2 million. Black Forest bought the 5050 Westheimer building in July 2010.Dawson, Jennifer. "[http://houston.bizjournals.com/houston/stories/2010/08/23/daily7.html Black Forest Ventures buys W. Houston facility]." ''[[Houston Business Journal]]''. Monday August 23, 2010. {{More citations needed|date=April 2018}} {{about|the animated television special|other uses|Lorax (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Lorax | image = | caption = | writer = [[Dr. Seuss]] | based_on = {{Based on|''[[The Lorax]]''|Dr. Seuss}} | director = [[Hawley Pratt]] | genre = [[Comedy]]/[[Fantasy]] | company = {{ubl|[[The Cat in the Hat|Cat in the Hat Productions]]|[[DePatie–Freleng Enterprises]]|[[CBS Productions]]}} | voices = {{ubl|[[Bob Holt (actor)|Bob Holt]]|Athena Lorde|Harlen Carraher|[[Thurl Ravenscroft]]|Matt Bennison}} | narrated = '''Introduced by:'''
[[Eddie Albert]] | composer = [[Dean Elliott]] | country = United States | language = English | executive_producer = [[David H. DePatie]] | producer = {{ubl|[[Friz Freleng]]|[[Dr. Seuss|Ted Geisel]]}} | runtime = 24 minutes | network = [[CBS]] | first_aired = February 14, 1972 }} '''''The Lorax''''' is a [[Musical film|musical]] [[animated short]] produced by [[DePatie–Freleng Enterprises]] which first aired as a [[television special]] on [[CBS]] on February 14, 1972. It is based on [[The Lorax|the book of the same name]] by [[Dr. Seuss]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLvABgAAQBAJ&pg=PA128 |title=The Dr. Seuss Catalog |last=Lindemann |first=Richard H.F |date=2005 |publisher=[[McFarland & Company]] |isbn=0-7864-2223-8 |page=128}} == Plot == One night, a young boy living in a polluted, grim world wanders down 'the street of the lifted Lorax.' Along the dark street, he comes to the residence of a creature named The Once-ler, a dark green-colored being whose face is never seen. He takes up an audience with the boy, and begins to explain the tale regarding the Lorax. The land once thrived with Truffula trees when the Once-ler first came to the area in a horse-drawn cart. Living among the foliage are the brown Bar-ba-Loots, who eat Truffula fruit from the local trees. In the nearby pond live the Humming Fish, and overhead fly the Swanee Swans. The trees amaze the Once-ler with their texture and scent, and he soon builds a small shop in the area. After cutting down a Truffula tree, the Lorax pops out of its stump. The Lorax claims to speak for the trees, and demands to know what the Once-ler is doing. The Once-ler explains that he is using the Truffula tree's tufts to make something called a "Thneed... a fine something that all people need." The multi-purpose item soon attracts the attention of many customers, and the Once-ler continues to cut down more Truffula trees. When it seems that the business is growing too big for just one Once-ler, he calls his relatives to help him with his thriving business. As the Lorax protests against the Once-ler's actions, he is eventually standing under a Truffula tree that was planted in the new developments that appeared over time, when a bulldozer picks up the Truffula tree and the Lorax and the Lorax is thrown into a truck with the Truffula tree and hauled to a factory, where the Lorax is put in a box. Then everybody reminisces about how Thneeds, Inc. started and how famous the Once-ler has become and popular the company has gotten, showing "Once-ler Cones", "Once-ler Burgers", a "Once-lermobile" and a blimp advertising Thneeds, then a stone with the word "Thneed" carved in it. Shortly after Thneeds, Inc. has produced its millionth product, the Lorax gets out of the box and, despite his protests, falls back into the box to be shipped off with more finished Thneeds. Soon the once beautiful area becomes choked with pollution and as the Once-ler is trying to find out how his company is doing in the Scandinavian market (by this point Thneeds, Inc. has expanded outside the US), the Lorax comes into the Once-Ler's office to protest that the Brown Bar-ba-loots, which fed on Truffula fruits, are nearing starvation. The Lorax starts sending the fauna off to more hospitable habitats. After this, the Once-ler's conscience tells him he is doing a lot of bad things, to which the Once-ler responds, "But if I didn't do them, then someone else would." When his conscience agrees, the Once-ler says progress has to get bigger. As the Once-ler is thinking about how successful Thneeds are selling all over the country, the Lorax protests that the "smogulous smoke" fills the Swanee Swans' throats with smog, preventing them from singing. Finally, the pond that was home to the Humming Fish is filled with toxic waste called "Gluppity-Glupp" and "Schloppity-Schlopp" that clogs their gills. Confronted by the Lorax, the Once-ler appears to be ready to listen. That is, until his secretary announces that the company's stock report has come in, and 'Thneeds, Inc' has exceeded its profit even higher due to rival markets closing down. The Once-ler then scoffs at the Lorax, claiming that he will keep on making Thneeds, regardless of the consequences. As he finishes his taunt, the sound of an ax is heard, and the two are witnesses to the leveling of the last Truffula tree. With no more trees, the factory shuts down, and the Once-ler's relatives pack up and leave. The Lorax sadly glances at the Once-ler, before he lifts himself by the seat of his pants, and disappears through a hole in the smog. On the spot where the Lorax last stood, sits a small pile of rocks, with a word carved into one: "Unless." The tale then switches back to the Once-ler talking to the boy, who is given the last Truffula seed by the Once-ler, encouraging the boy to help revitalize the long-dead trees by growing a brand new forest, with the possibility that the Lorax and all of his friends may then come back. The camera shows us a larger hole in the smog, which is the background image to the end credits. == Cast == *[[Eddie Albert]] – Narrator *[[Bob Holt (actor)|Bob Holt]] – The Lorax, the Once-Ler *Athena Lorde – Ms. Funce-ler *[[Harlen Carraher]] – Humming Fish *[[Thurl Ravenscroft]] – Singer *Matt Bennison – Ted == Credits == *Production Design by: Maurice Noble *Directed by: Hawley Pratt *Produced by: Friz Freleng and Ted Geisel *Executive Producer: David H. DePatie *Animation: Warren Batchelder, John Gibbs, Manny Gould, Bob Matz, Bob Richardson, Robert Taylor, Dick Thompson, Don Williams *Backgrounds: Richard H. Thomas *Camera: John Burton, Jr., Larry Hogan, Ray Lee *Film Editing: Lee Gunther, Joe Siracusa, Rick Steward *Executive In Charge of Production: Stan Paperny *Production Supervision: Harry Love *The Songs **Lyrics by: Dr. Seuss **Music by: Dean Elliott *Production Mixer: Steve Orr *Teleplay by: Dr. Seuss *Storyboard by: Irv Spector == Home release == ''The Lorax'' was released on [[VHS]] in 1994 as part of a [[CBS Video]] four-tape package called "Dr. Seuss Sing-Along Classics".{{cite news|last1=Fitzpatrick|first1=Eileen|title=Sing-Along Seuss Titles Coming from CBS Video|journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=May 21, 1994|pages=53,56|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TAgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA53|accessdate=April 20, 2018|location=Los Angeles}} To tie-in with the 40th anniversary of the special and the release of film ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]'', [[Warner Home Video]] released the special on a deluxe edition [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray]] on February 14, 2012.[http://www.wbshop.com/Lorax-The-Deluxe-Edition/1000232243,default,pd.html?cgid=PRE Lorax, The: Deluxe Edition DVD – Warner Bros.: WBshop.com – The Official Online Store of Warner Bros. Studios] == Reception == ''The Lorax'' received the Critics Award from the [[International Animated Cartoon Festival]] (Zagreb, 1972) and the Silver Media from the [[International Film and Television Festival]] (New York, 1972).{{cite book|editor1-last=Cullinan|editor1-first=Bernice E.|editor2-last=Person|editor2-first=Diane G|title=The Continuum Encyclopedia of Children's Literature|date=2005|isbn=0-8264-1516-4|page=710|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0LyutQg6mroC&pg=PA710}} == References == == External links == *{{IMDb title|id=0213065|title=The Lorax}} {{DePatie-Freleng Enterprises}} {{Dr. Seuss}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lorax, The}} [[Category:1972 television specials]] [[Category:1972 animated films]] [[Category:Television programs based on works by Dr. Seuss]] [[Category:Television programs written by Dr. Seuss]] [[Category:CBS television specials]] [[Category:Films featuring anthropomorphic characters]] [[Category:Children's fantasy films]] [[Category:Animated television specials]] [[Category:American animated fantasy films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Musical television specials]] [[Category:Environmental films]] [[Category:Television specials by DePatie–Freleng Enterprises]] [[Category:1970s American animated films]] [[Category:Films scored by Dean Elliott]]

{{Use British English|date=January 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} The '''Wee Shu Min elitism controversy''' occurred in October 2006 in [[Singapore]]. Wee Shu Min, daughter of [[Parliament of Singapore|parliament member]] [[Wee Siew Kim]] and a then eighteen-year-old student on Raffles Junior College's Humanities scholarship programme, found herself in controversy<ref>{{cite web|last=Ken Kwek|first=Aaron Low|title=Internet users learning netiquette the hard way|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/Free/Story/STIStory_142321.html|work=Straits Times |location=Singapore |accessdate=25 July 2007}}</ref> after posting on her blog what were viewed by some Singaporeans to be [[ivory tower|elitist]],<ref name="satrev">''"Time to learn that sorry isn't the hardest word to say"'', Ong Soh Chin, [[The Straits Times]] (Saturday Review), 28 October 2006, p. S10</ref> naïve, and insensitive statements against heartlanders.<ref name="shuminblog">''"Teen blogger counselled for her 'elitist' remarks"'', Ken Kewk, [[The Straits Times]], 24 October 2006, p. H5</ref>
Dismissing the [http://derekwee.blogspot.com/ views of Derek Wee] who voiced concerns on [[job security]] and [[age discrimination]] on his blog, she shot back with a take-no-prisoners diatribe,<ref name="satrev" /><ref name="zbedit">''""精英"博客的省思"'', 社论观点, [[Lianhe Zaobao]], 31 October 2006 (Chinese)</ref> calling Derek a ''"stupid crackpot"'', belonging to ''"the sadder class"'' and overreliant on the government. Her post also called for Derek to ''"get out of my elite uncaring face".<ref>[http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2006/12/“please-get-out-of-my-elite-uncaring-face”/ The Online Citizen] 1 Dec 2006. Accessed 9 Jan 2014.</ref>
Her response triggered an avalanche of criticism, as it came on the heels of the sensational suicide of an individual (said to be facing financial difficulties) at [[Chinese Garden MRT Station]].<ref>''"妻子连搭车去认尸的钱都没有…… 跳轨男子山穷水尽走绝路"'', 林晓玲、杨荣发, [[Lianhe Zaobao]], 20 October 2006 (Chinese)</ref><ref name="nst">''[http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/10/29/focus/15847372&;;sec=focus "Political elitism enhances class divide"]'', Seah Chiang Nee, [[The Star (Malaysia)]], 29 October 2006</ref> As a result, her name topped [[Technorati]]'s search terms for a week.<ref name="asiatimes">"''[http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/HK23Ae02.html Mixing welfare and elitism in Singapore]''", Alex Au, [[Asia Times]], 23 November 2006</ref> She has since appeared to have apologised<ref>[http://weikiatblog.blogspot.com/2006/10/wee-shu-mins-apology.html Wei Kiat's blog: Wee Shu Min's apology], 19 Oct 2006. Accessed 13 Nov 2006.</ref> on another blog and shut down her own.<ref name="shuminblog" />
A few months after the controversy, Wee Shu Min flew to US to study her BA in [[University of Pennsylvania|University of Pennysylvania]]. In 2011, she graduated from University of Pennsylvania. She proceeded to study a MBA in [[Stanford Graduate School of Business|Stanford University Graduate School]] of Business and graduated in 2016. Taking a different direction from her initial "Get out of my uncaring elite face", she did a video documenting her own fear of imperfection in Stanford with the SNATCHED show. However, it was not well received as many could not believe what she had shared on the video. As of 2017, she is currently working in [[Lyft]] as a Senior Manager in Driver Loyalty and Experience.
== Response == In response to the scandal, Wee Siew Kim stated that he supported Shu Min's point in principle and that "''people cannot take the brutal truth,''"<ref name="asiatimes" /><ref name="review">''"A season of sorrys and a few pitfalls"'', ''Straits Times'' columnist Chua Mui Hoong, ''[[The Straits Times]]'' (Insight Editorial), 27 October 2006, p. 33</ref> but he and Shu Min's college principal also expressed disappointment and counselled her to be more sensitive towards others. Wee also claimed that his daughter's privacy had been violated.<ref name="shuminblog" /> Critics pointed out however, that he appeared to have endorsed her elitist remarks and failed to address values such as empathy and humility, and that he was apologising for the tone, but not the content of his daughter's response.<ref name="insit">''"Insensitive blogger also lacked humility, empathy"'', Yang Sixiang, ''[[The Straits Times]]'' Forum, 26 October 2006, p. H8</ref>
== Public backlash == Two days after Wee Siew Kim first spoke out in ''[[The Straits Times]]'', he made a public apology to those who were offended by statements made in his interview, in particular Derek Wee.<ref>''"Wee Siew Kim apologises for remarks"'', Ken Kwek, ''[[The Straits Times]]'', 26 October 2006, p. H4</ref> Commentators used the controversy as evidence that Singapore was suffering from increasing signs that [[elitism|political elitism]], "smarter-than-thou" snobbery and [[class consciousness]] anxiety were creeping into its [[meritocratic|meritocracy]] model,<ref>"''How meritocracy can breed intellectual elitism''", Chua Mui Hoong, ''[[The Straits Times]]'' (Friday Matters), 10 November 2006, p. 37</ref><ref name="npsim">"''MP Sin Boon Ann warns Parliament of social divide''", Clarence Chang, ''[[The New Paper]]'', 10 November 2006</ref><ref>"''Is meritocracy what it is made out to be?''", Law Kim Hwee, [[The Straits Times]] Forum, 9 December 2006</ref><ref name="eanxiety">"''High anxiety an elite affliction?''", Ken Kwek, [[The Straits Times]], 19 May 2007</ref> a widening [[social stratification]] that will cause long-term implications for Singaporean society,<ref name="nst" /> and [[Education in Singapore#Criticisms|problems in the education system]] that need to be addressed.<ref name="zbedit" /><ref name="schoolsurvey">"''Students of top schools worry more about elitism''", Ken Kwek, [[The Straits Times]], 18 May 2007</ref> The controversy was subsequently raised and hotly debated again in the opening session of the [[Parliament of Singapore|Parliament]] by fellow MP [[Sin Boon Ann]], who pointed out that elitism was now an open secret in several aspects of Singapore society, including education, the [[Singapore Armed Forces|military]] and the civil service, commenting that it is necessary "(to) ''break down the institution of snobbery within our society.''"<ref name="asiatimes" /><ref name="npsim" />

{{infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Wild Goose Festival | image = [[Image:Wild-Goose-Festival.JPG|200px]] | caption = Mainstage at Wild Goose Festival 2011. | location = Shakori Hills farm | years_active = 2011 – present | founders = | dates = June 23–26, 2011 | genre = Mixed | website = [http://www.wildgoosefestival.org wildgoosefestival.org] }}
The '''[http://wildgoosefestival.org/ Wild Goose Festival]'''<ref name="Wild Goose Festival">{{cite web|url=http://www.wildgoosefestival.org/ |title=Wild Goose Festival |publisher=Wild Goose Festival |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2017-01-29}}</ref> is an art, music, and story-driven transformational experience grounded in faith-inspired social justice. The nationwide annual July event is attended by 2,000 to 3,000 in Hot Springs, NC. There are also some regional events. It encourages co-creation of music, story, theater, and spectacle, and engagement in a wide variety of robust, respectful conversations with participants and with thought leaders and artists from other communities. Wild Goose is welcoming and hospitable to people of all faiths – or no faith – who join in seeking the common good. It fully affirms and celebrates people of every age, ethnicity, gender, gender expression, sexual identity, education, bodily condition, religious affiliation, and economic background, particularly those who are most often marginalized.
Wild Goose is rooted in [[Progressive Christianity]], moving beyond belief and centered in justice and compassion, in solidarity with the marginalized and the oppressed. The festival is popular among many involved with the [[emerging church movement]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/06/19/progressive-christians-to_n_879530.html |title='Wild Goose': A New Kind Of Christian Revival |publisher=The Huffington Post |date= |accessdate=2017-01-29}}</ref>
The Wild Goose Community is [http://wildgoosefestival.org/wild-goose-invitation/ committed]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://wildgoosefestival.org/wild-goose-invitation/|title=Wild Goose Invitation - Wild Goose Festival|work=Wild Goose Festival|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en-US}}</ref> to Co-Creation, Storytelling, Radical Hospitality. Real Relationship, Non-Violence, and Continual Evolution.
==History== The Wild Goose Festival was inspired in by the popular [[Greenbelt festival]] in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Wild Goose Festival — History">{{cite web|url=http://www.wildgoosefestival.org/about-us/history/|title=History|date=2014-06-20|publisher=Wild Goose Festival|accessdate=2017-01-29}}</ref> The board of directors for the Wild Goose Festival was formed in 2009, and [[Gareth Higgins]] was hired as festival director in March 2010. Rosa Lee Hardin succeeded Gareth in 2013, and in 2016 Rosa Lee was succeeded by Jeff Clark.
The first festival was held June 23–26, 2011, at Shakori Hills farm (home of the [[Shakori Hills Grassroots Festival]]) in [[Silk Hope, North Carolina]]. It was attended by an estimated 1,500 people.<ref name="Economist article">{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18898389|title=A broader church|date=2011-06-30|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|accessdate=2017-01-29}}</ref> Music at the 2011 festival included [[Michelle Shocked]], [[David Wilcox (American musician)|David Wilcox]], [[Over the Rhine (band)|Over The Rhine]], [[Jennifer Knapp]], [[Derek Webb]], [[David Bazan]], [[David LaMotte|David Lamotte]], Tom Prasada-Rao, [[Ashley Cleveland]], Agents of Future, [[Sarah Masen]], Psalters, [[Denison Witmer]], and [[The Redding Brothers]].
Speakers at the 2011 festival included [[Jim Wallis]], [[Brian McLaren]], [[T-Bone Burnett]], [[Richard Rohr|Father Richard Rohr]], [[Phyllis Tickle]], [[Vincent Harding]], [[John Dear]], [[Shane Claiborne]], Lynne Hybels, [[Tony Campolo]], [[Diana Butler Bass]], Paul Knitter, Soong-Chan Rah, [[Frank Schaeffer]], [[Jay Bakker]], [[Peter Rollins]], [[Doug Pagitt]], [[Richard Twiss]], Carl McColman, Tony Jones, Margot Starbuck, Ian Cron, [[David Dark]], [[Jonathan Wilson-Hartgrove]], [[Nadia Bolz-Weber]], Mark Scandrette, [[Ed Dobson]], Paul Fromberg, Melvin Bray, Cynthia La Grou, [[Eliacin Rosario-Cruz]], Anthony Smith, [[Samir Selmanovic]], Chad Holtz, Becky Knight, Kester Brewin, and Pamela Wilhelms.
In 2012, festivals were held in Shakori Hills, North Carolina and in Portland, Oregon. The festival moved to Hot Springs, North Carolina in 2013 and has continued there to the present day.

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = William Owen Smith | image = William Owen Smith.jpg | alt = man with moustache in Victorian suit | caption = | imagesize = 170px | spouse = Mary Abbey Hobron | birth_date = {{birth date|1848|8|4}} | birth_place = [[Koloa, Hawaii|Kōloa]], [[Kauai|Kauaʻi]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1929|4|13|1848|8|4}} | death_place = [[Honolulu]] | children = | occupation = Lawyer | office = [[Republic of Hawaii]]
[[Attorney General of Hawaii|Attorney General]] | term_start = November 6, 1895 | term_end = March 20, 1899 | president = [[Sanford B. Dole]] | predecessor = | successor = [[Henry Ernest Cooper|Henry E. Cooper]] }} '''William Owen Smith''' (August 4, 1848 – April 13, 1929) was a lawyer from a family of American [[List of Missionaries to Hawaii|missionaries]] who participated in the [[overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]]. He served as [[Attorney General of Hawaii|attorney general]] for the entire duration of the [[provisional Government of Hawaii]] and the [[Republic of Hawaii]]. ==Life== Smith was born August 4, 1848 in [[Koloa, Hawaii|Kōloa]] on the island of [[Kauai|Kauaʻi]]. His mother was Millicent Knapp (1816–1891). His parents were physician James William Smith (1810–1887) and teacher [[Melicent Knapp Smith]] (1816-1891).{{cite book |title=Portraits of American Protestant missionaries to Hawaii |author=Hawaiian Mission Children's Society |url= https://archive.org/details/portraitsofameri00hawarich |year=1901 |location=Honolulu |publisher=Hawaiian gazette co. |page=78 }} His parents were in the tenth set of [[List of Missionaries to Hawaii|missionaries to Hawaii]] from the [[American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions]] who arrived in 1842.{{cite web |title=Smith Family Records |publisher=Kauaʻi Historical Society |url= http://www.kauaihistoricalsociety.org/assets/finding_aids/ms_43_smith_family.pdf |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} His sister Charlotte Elizabeth "Lottie" Smith (1845–1896) married [[Alfred S. Hartwell|Alfred Stedman Hartwell]] (1836–1912), who was a former general in the [[American Civil War]], on January 10, 1872. His brother Jared Knapp Smith (1849–1897) became a physician and carried on his father's medical practice. His sister Melicent Lena Smith (1854–1943) married William Waterhouse (1852–1942). Waterhouse served as [[Pasadena City Council|mayor]] of [[Pasadena, California]] 1904–1906.{{cite book| author=J. W. Wood |title=Pasadena, California, historical and personal: a complete history of the organization of the Indiana colony, its establishment on the Rancho San Pascual and its evolution into the city of Pasadena |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YxQpAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA210 |year=1917 |pages=210–212}} He attended [[Daniel Dole]]'s missionary school at Kōloa, [[Punahou School]] from 1863 to 1866,{{cite book |author=[[William DeWitt Alexander]] |title=Oahu College: list of trustees, presidents, instructors, matrons, librarians, superintendents of grounds and students, 1841–1906. Historical sketch of Oahu College |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GxADAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA80 |year=1907 |publisher=Hawaiian Gazette Company |pages=79–80 }} and then Massachusetts Agricultural College (now the [[University of Massachusetts Amherst]]).{{cite book |author1=Henry Hill Goodsell |author2=Frederick Tuckerman |title=General catalogue of the Massachusetts Agricultural College, including the ofiicers of government and instruction, sketches of the alumni, occupations and addresses of the non-graduates, and other matters of interest relating to the college. 1862–1886 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZiFDAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA89 |year=1886 |publisher=J. E. Williams, printer |page=89}} On his return he worked as a clerk in his brother-in-law Hartwell's law office. He served as sheriff on Kauaʻi in 1870 and then [[Maui]] in 1872 through 1874. While working at the [[Lahaina Banyan Court Park|Lāhainā Courthouse]], on April 24, 1873 he planted a banyan tree (''[[Ficus benghalensis]]'') to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the arrival of Christian missionaries on the island.{{cite book |author=John R. K. Clark |title= Hawai'i place names: shores, beaches, and surf sites |publisher=[[University of Hawaii Press]] |year= 2001 |isbn= 978-0-8248-2451-8 |page= 23 |url= http://www.ulukau.org/elib/cgi-bin/library?c=cpn&l=en }} On March 23, 1876, he married Mary Abbey Hobron. They had five children: Clarence Hobron Smith, Ethel Frances Smith born November 17, 1879, Pauline Melicent Smith, Anna Katherine Smith, and Lorrin Knapp Smith.{{cite book |title= Men of Hawaii: being a biographical reference library, complete and authentic, of the men of note and substantial achievement in the Hawaiian Islands |publisher=[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |year=1921 |editor=John William Siddall |page= 365 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4o8DAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA365 }} He founded the law firm of Smith, Thurston & Kinney with [[Lorrin A. Thurston]] and [[William Ansel Kinney]] in [[Honolulu]] in 1887. ==Politics== He acted as deputy attorney general, and was elected as a representative from Maui to the [[legislature of the Hawaiian Kingdom]] from 1878 to 1884. He helped draft the [[1887 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii]], which King [[Kalākaua]] was forced to sign, giving it the name "Bayonet Constitution". His law partner Thurston then became minister in the new cabinet. In the 1887 and 1888 sessions he was elected to the upper House of Nobles. In 1892 he was elected as representative from Kauaʻi. ===Overthrow=== [[File:Hawaii Provisional Government Cabinet (PP-28-7-012).jpg|thumb|alt=four men and desk|Provisional cabinet: (left to right) [[James A. King|J. A. King]], [[Sanford B. Dole|Dole]], Smith, [[Peter Cushman Jones|P. C. Jones]] ]] He was a member of the [[Committee of Safety (Hawaii)|Committee of Safety]] that organized the [[overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]] on January 14, 1893. On January 17, he was appointed to the executive council (the new cabinet) of the [[Provisional Government of Hawaii]] under president [[Sanford B. Dole]], the son of his former teacher. Dole's stepmother, Charlotte Close Knapp (1813–1874), was widow of Smith's uncle Horton Owen Knapp (1813–1845), who had been a missionary teacher himself on Kauaʻi.{{cite book |author1=R. Thomas Collins |author2=Joseph S. Wood |title=One Life at a Time: A New World Family Narrative, 1630–1960 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TW4Vz7T8zxwC&pg=PA122 |date=March 1999 |publisher=RavensYard Publishing |isbn=978-0-9667883-0-3 |page=122}} Smith served as [[Attorney General of Hawaii]] from the creation of provisional government through the [[Republic of Hawaii]]. On December 18, 1895 he became a member of the board of health, and later its president. He had no formal training except for having a father and brother as practicing physicians. ===Murder in the family=== His brother Jared Knapp Smith was shot dead on September 24, 1897. It was suspected to be in retaliation for ordering patients suspected of [[leprosy]] to have tests that might send them to exile in [[Kalaupapa Leprosy Settlement and National Historical Park|Kalaupapa]]. Similar tensions had ignited the [[Leper War on Kaua'i]] four years earlier. His former law partner Kinney sailed to [[Kauai|Kaua{{okina}}i]] island and was appointed special prosecutor. A native Hawaiian suspect Kapea Ka{{okina}}ahea was arrested, tried on November 13, 1897, and found guilty of murder in the first degree.{{cite news |url= http://hdl.handle.net/10524/564 |title= Murder, a Trial, a Hanging: The Kapea Case of 1897–1898 |work=Hawaiian Journal of History |publisher=Hawaii Historical Society |volume= 42 |author1= Esther Kwon Arinaga |author2= Caroline Axtell Garrett |year= 2008 |pages= 201–230 |accessdate=August 15, 2010 }} Instead of waiting for next scheduled term of the circuit court, a special session had been called. Honolulu English-language newspapers said "there seems no doubt of the guilt of the chief prisoner" even before the trial.{{cite news |title= Lodged in Jail: Murderers of Dr. Smith Were Captured |newspaper=The Hawaiian gazette |location= Honolulu |date= October 5, 1897 |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1897-10-05/ed-1/seq-1/ |page= 1 |accessdate=August 19, 2010}} The objections brought to the [[Supreme Court of Hawaii]] were quickly rejected on February 3, 1898.{{cite book |author=Hawaii Supreme Court |title=Reports of decisions rendered by the Supreme Court of the Hawaiian Islands |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1K5LAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA293 |year=1899 |publisher=H. L. Sheldon |chapter= Republic of Hawaii v. Kapea, Kaio and Upapa |pages=293–314 }} Kapea was hanged on April 11, 1898. The rushed nature of the prosecution was thought to be an attempt to show the United States that the government was in firm control. Only a few months later in July 1898, the [[Newlands Resolution]] would annex the islands. Of the four executions for capital punishment between 1889 and 1903 in Hawaii, all four were of non-whites within a four-month period. ===Return to private practice=== In August 1898 Smith offered to resign, but although now annexed, the old republic government continued to operate.{{cite news |title= King Bill the First |newspaper=The Independent |location= Honolulu |date= March 16, 1899 |url= http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1899-03-16/ed-1/seq-2/ |page= 2 |accessdate=August 19, 2010}} On March 20, 1899, Smith was replaced as attorney general by [[Henry Ernest Cooper]] and returned to private practice. Smith was elected to one term of the [[Territory of Hawaii]] senate from 1907 to 1909.{{cite web |url= http://archives1.dags.hawaii.gov/gsdl/collect/governme/index/assoc/HASH01e2/28c60283.dir/Smith,%20William%20Owen.jpg |title= Smith, William Owen, office record |work=state archives digital collections |publisher=state of Hawaii |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} Smith was a trustee of the [[Kamehameha Schools]], founded from the estate of [[Bernice Pauahi Bishop]], from 1884 to 1886 and from 1897 to 1929.{{cite web |title= First Years: Trustees: William Owen Smith (1848–1929) |work=The Kamehameha Schools Archives |url= http://kapalama.ksbe.edu/archives/FirstYears/links/smith.php |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} He was a trustee of the [[Lunalilo]] Estate, the [[Alexander Young (Hawaii)|Alexander Young]] Estate and the Honolulu children's hospital. He was on the board of the Guardian Trust Company, Bishop Trust Company, Inter-Island Steam Navigation company and [[Alexander & Baldwin]]. Despite his role in the overthrow, deposed [[Liliuokalani|Queen Lili{{okina}}uokalani]] selected him to be a founding trustee of her own estate when she made her will in December 1909.{{cite web |title= Queen Lili‘uokalani’s Deed of Trust |url= http://www.onipaa.org/resources/deed_deed_1.pdf |publisher=The Queen Liliuokalani Trust |accessdate=August 13, 2010 }} Her personal assets were left in a trust to benefit orphans.{{cite news |title= Ex-Queen to Endow Orphans: Liliuokalani Makes Trust So Disposing of Bulk of Property After Death |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date= December 4, 1909 |url= https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1909/12/04/106123090.pdf |format= pdf |accessdate=August 17, 2010 }} On November 30, 1915, [[Jonah Kūhiō Kalaniana'ole|Prince Jonah Kūhiō Kalaniana{{okina}}ole]] challenged the will in court, saying she was "of weakened mind" under the influence of the trustees. This was known as case 23 Haw. 457 in the Supreme Court of Hawaii. The feisty queen demanded a public hearing of her sanity in February 1916. The firm, now Smith, Warren & Sutton, successfully defended Lili{{okina}}uokalani.{{cite book |author=Hawaii Supreme Court |title=Hawaiian reports: cases decided in the Supreme Court of the Territory of Hawaii |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wckDAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA457 |volume= 23 |year=1917 |publisher=Honolulu Star-Bulletin |pages=457–476 }} His law partners at the time were Louis J. Warren and Edwin White Sutton.{{cite book |author=Maryland Casualty Company |title=Lawyers list |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ri4UAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA62 |year=1917 |publisher=H.R. Brown |page=62}} Lili{{okina}}uokalani's charity still operates today.{{cite web |work=official web site |url= http://www.onipaa.org/ |title= The Queen Liliuokalani Trust |accessdate=August 17, 2010 }} ==Legacy== [[File:Banyan-tree-Lahaina-Hawaii.jpg|thumb|alt=enormous tree|[[Ficus benghalensis|Banyan tree]] he planted in 1873 still stands in [[Lahaina, Hawaii|Lāhainā]] ]] His daughter Ethel Frances Smith (1879–1967) married [[Henry Alexander Baldwin]], known as "Harry" Baldwin who briefly became the [[Hawaii Territory's At-large congressional district|congressional delegate for Hawaii]]. Daughter Anna Katherine Smith (1888–1960) married Harry's brother Samuel Alexander Baldwin (1885–1950) and lived on Maui. The father of his two sons-in-law was [[Henry Perrine Baldwin]], founder of Alexander & Baldwin. Clarence Hobron Smith married Margherita Adele Browning May 7, 1908 in New York. They then moved to [[Italy]].{{cite book |author=Hawaiian Mission Children's Society |title=Annual report |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wwBNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA53 |year=1920 |page=53}} Youngest son Lorrin Knapp Smith was born October 10, 1890, married Sila Pratt (1890–1952), became a ranch manager on Maui, and died October 27, 1930. The Maui branches of the family are buried in the cemetery at [[Makawao Union Church]].{{cite web |title= Makawao Cemetery, Makawao, Maui County, Hawaii |author=S. Viehweg |date= October 2004 |url= http://files.usgwarchives.org/hi/maui/cemeteries/makawao.txt |accessdate=August 19, 2010 }} His niece Madeline Perry Hartwell married Albert Francis Judd, Jr., son of Chief Justice of the Hawaii Supreme Court [[Albert Francis Judd]] on July 21, 1899.{{cite book |title= A record of the descendants of Dr. Gerrit P. Judd of Hawaii, March 8, 1829, to April 16, 1922 |date= July 1922 |editors= [[George R. Carter]] and Mary H. Hopkins |url= https://archive.org/details/recordofdescenda00cart |publisher=Hawaiian Historical Society }} His ties to the oligarchy known as the "[[Big Five (Hawaii)|Big Five]]" that dominated the island economy led the opposition press to call him "King Bill the First". They described him using a mix of stereotypes:
He was narrow-minded as a New Englander, domineering as a Russian Czar, yet suave as a Frenchman. He was obstinate as a Scotchman, generous as a Southerner, and at times vicious as an Indian. But he was withal the hardest working official we have ever heard of—next to the Devil.
In 1926 he was appointed to help organize the public archives of Hawaii. He donated many of his papers to the collection, including drafts of the 1887 constitution.{{cite book |author=David W. Forbes |title=Hawaiian national bibliography, 1780–1900 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jAuzOipG26YC&pg=PA232 |year=2003 |publisher=University of Hawaii Press |isbn=978-0-8248-2636-9 |pages=232–233}} Smith died April 13, 1929 in his home in the [[Nuuanu Valley|Nu{{okina}}uanu Valley]] near Honolulu from [[pneumonia]]. After a number of partner changes, his law firm survives as Case Lombardi & Pettit.{{cite web |work=official web site |url= http://www.caselombardi.com/aboutHistory.aspx |title= An Uncommon History |publisher=Case Lombardi & Pettit, A Law Corporation – Honolulu, Hawaii |accessdate=August 18, 2010 }} Partner Daniel H. Case is the father of [[Steve Case]] and uncle of Congressman [[Ed Case]]. Case was lawyer for [[Grove Farm (Lihue, Hawaii)|Grove Farm]], when it was bought by his son.{{cite news |title= Grove Farm – a house divided: Litigation that divides family stems from sale clouded in suspicions |date= April 23, 2006 |author=Stewart Yerton |newspaper=[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]] |url= http://archives.starbulletin.com/2006/04/23/news/story03.html |accessdate=August 17, 2010 }} It includes the area where Smith grew up. Other notable members of the firm through the years included [[Cyrus Nils Tavares]], [[Alan Cooke Kay]], and [[William Stanley (Hawaii)|W. F.L. Stanley]]. ==References== {{commons category}} {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-gov}} {{succession box| title= [[Republic of Hawaii]] Attorney General | before= [[Arthur P. Peterson]] | after= [[Henry Ernest Cooper|Henry E. Cooper]] | years= 1893–1899 }} {{s-end}} {{Hawaiian Ministers of Foreign Affairs}} {{Attorneys General of Hawaii}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Smith, William Owen}} [[Category:1848 births]] [[Category:1929 deaths]] [[Category:Kingdom of Hawaii politicians]] [[Category:Republic of Hawaii politicians]] [[Category:Members of the Kingdom of Hawaii House of Representatives]] [[Category:Members of the Kingdom of Hawaii House of Nobles]] [[Category:Republic of Hawaii Foreign Ministers]] [[Category:Republic of Hawaii Attorneys General]] [[Category:Hawaii lawyers]] [[Category:Hawaii Attorneys General]] [[Category:People associated with the Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii]] [[Category:People of the Republic of Hawaii]] [[Category:Independent (Kuokoa) Party politicians]]
